metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit TestsOutside of alien conspiracy theories — this guy is a big advocate of writing unit tests with truth tablesA few years ago, I was working at a small startup that was heavy into testing which was a huge mental shift for me, as I had spent the last two years at a much larger company writing somewhere around 0 tests.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: larger company writing somewhere around 0 tests. Yup, my previous company relied on a QA team to painstakingly test all the scenarios of user behavior we could dream up before shipping our code into the wild. Surprisingly, this worked for the most part.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: wild. Surprisingly, this worked for the most part. While not writing tests certainly made development faster (initially at least), unit tests are the standard at most modern tech companies and now I found myself struggling not only with the syntax for writing unit and integration tests, but the entire idea was so foreign I often didn’t know where to begin. When testing a component or method that could have many permutations, my tests would look something like this://coolMethod.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tests would look something like this://coolMethod. jsconst maybeTruncate = (word, length = 5) => { if(. word. length){ return 'N/A'; } return word. length > length. `${word. slice(0, length)}. ` : word;}//coolMethod. spec. jsit('supports long words', () => { expect(maybeTruncate('really big word')). to. equal('reall. ')})it('supports short words', () => { expect(maybeTruncate('short')). to.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: { expect(maybeTruncate('short')). to. equal('short')})it('supports custom length', () => { expect(maybeTruncate('kinda big', 10)). to. equal('kinda big')})it('supports no word', () => { expect(maybeTruncate('')). to. equal('N/A')})A wise developer on my team reviewed my code one day, and looking at a test similar to the one above, offered me some good advice: ‘Stop writing tests like that you fool’ or something to that effect.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: like that you fool’ or something to that effect. He was a bit eccentric, even by software developer standards. He then opened his magical bag of coding tricks and showed me the way he wrote tests. Now this wise guy was particularly suited to offer testing advice as he had written a popular library for EmberJS developers to mock data and this small nugget of testing knowledge he shared with me has stuck with me since.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: he shared with me has stuck with me since. Using Truth TablesA truth table is usually used in Boolean Algebra to express the mathematical outcome produced from a combination of values. We can apply this same logic to creating tests by writing a set of conditions and the expected outcome. This not only makes our code easier to reason about, it also makes more concise tests that can be easily modified to add different conditions to test when our function or component inevitably changes.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: when our function or component inevitably changes. Refactoring the above test to use truth tables would look something like this:const tests = [ //test word length expected ['no word', '', undefined, 'N/A'], ['short word', 'Short', undefined, 'Short'], ['long word', 'Not so short', undefined, 'Not s. '], ['custom length', 'Not short', 15, 'Not short'],]test.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: short', 15, 'Not short'],]test. forEach((test) => { const [assertion, word, length, expected] = test; it(`supports ${assertion}`, () => { expect(maybeTruncate(word, length)). to. equal(expected) })})Now, when a new scenario needs to be tested, it’s as simple as inserting some values to our truth table and letting our test suite run its course.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: table and letting our test suite run its course. This cuts down on boilerplate code and overly verbose tests and also explicitly defines the input possibilities we should be aware of instead of searching through a set of tests to find weird edge cases.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: through a set of tests to find weird edge cases. ConclusionWriting tests is an art form in itself and although I initially didn’t see the value in them, I’ve come to appreciate how they catch scenarios I didn’t initially prepare for and also can make you feel a lot more comfortable when refactoring code that isn’t yours. A strong test suite with good coverage can make you more confident that your change on line 183 in a five year old file didn’t break something further down the pipeline.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: didn’t break something further down the pipeline. Truth tables are hopefully a pattern you can use to make your tests more concise, explicit and perhaps more importantly, more fun to write.

metadata.title: Using Truth Tables to Write Better Unit Tests
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Thank you. This was the explanation I was looking for — makes so much sense now.

metadata.title: Thank you! This was the explanation I was looking for — makes so much sense now
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So FarAnd how to avoid themI’d like to attribute any git commit of mine in the first year (or two) to someone else. anyone elseIn the better part of the last decade, I’ve written a lot of code, and now, through the lens of experience, I see just how bad some of that code was. How bad you ask.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: how bad some of that code was. How bad you ask. Well, let me explain…The 100+ Line if else statementOne of my first projects on my first job was to write a program that checked whether or not a refund should be issued to a store based on a number of criteria. I created a spreadsheet with all the possible scenarios and began coding up the mother of all if-else statements. It was well over 100 lines long but it worked.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: It was well over 100 lines long but it worked. I used to mistake something working for being done, but in general, refactoring a working solution should be part on any development process. As a rule of thumb, when I see a lot of conditional statements in code I try to replace that logic using an object.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: code I try to replace that logic using an object. While the logic for my refund program was fairly complex, a more palatable example of refactoring a conditional statement to make use of an object might look like this:// icon logicconst getIcon = (input) => { if('twitter'){ return <TwitterIcon/> } if('facebook'){ return <FacebookIcon/> } if('instagram'){ return <InstagramIcon/> } if('pinterest'){ return <PinterestIcon/> }}// better icon logicconst ICON_MAP = { 'pinterest': <PinterestIcon/>, 'facebook': <FacebookIcon/>, 'twitter': <TwitterIcon/>, 'instagram': <InstagramIcon/>}const getIcon = (input) => { return ICON_MAP[input]}This refactor makes the code much less verbose and easy to reason about.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: code much less verbose and easy to reason about. Adding more conditions is pretty trivial now. The more area your code covers, the more space for little bugs to hide. Keeping things succinct leaves less space for bugs and places less cognitive load for future developers. That Time Every Customer Got Sent an EmailAt a small startup I was using Ruby which was completely new to me and I was doing a large refactor of a service we used to update invoices.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: refactor of a service we used to update invoices. There was an enum we were using that maps a string value to an integer value in our database.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: string value to an integer value in our database. Not exactly knowing how enums work in Ruby at the time (and probably not now either — it’s been a while), I simply added another value to this enumclass Invoice < ActiveRecord::Base enum status: { active: 0, archived: 1 }endclass Invoice < ActiveRecord::Base enum status: { pending: 0, active: 1 archived: 2}endThis change had the unintended affect of flagging our archived invoices as active and some other piece of logic that detected this change then sent status updates to nearly all our customers.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: sent status updates to nearly all our customers. Whoops. After pushing my changes, we noticed we were sending tons of emails to our customers. While it wasn’t a critical meltdown of our system, it definitely was a situation we would have liked to avoid. The takeaway here was to admit when you don’t know how something works instead of assuming. This is a lesson I sometimes find myself re-learning.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is a lesson I sometimes find myself re-learning. As uncomfortable as it can be, exposing your ignorance is an important practice that you and the rest of your team will benefit from. I definitely notice that the senior members of a team are (usually) more willing to publicly declare that they aren’t sure how that thing that you assumed everyone was supposed to know(but that you also don’t really get) is supposed to really work.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: also don’t really get) is supposed to really work. The Review that Wasn’tThis isn’t really a piece of code I wrote, but I definitely shared the blame in the effects of this blunder. At my current company, when I was still fairly new, I was reviewing some code from a pretty talented developer on our team. I made a quick pass over the code using GitHub’s file diff view and everything looked pretty good. I ran the branch locally and quickly made sure that everything worked.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and quickly made sure that everything worked. He’s a good developer and nothing seemed obviously broken, plus I had my own work to attend to, I couldn’t be spending too much time on a review, I had real work that needed to be done. A week later, that code went to our staging environment and had some glaring issues that either one of us should have caught. People wondered why we hadn’t. Double oops.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: People wondered why we hadn’t. Double oops. Reviewing code takes as long as it has to, and diving into edge cases, comparing design specs with what’s on the screen and even checking that tests cover all the expected functionality will usually surface bugs that a quick pass over won’t catch. One of my goals after that embarrassing episode was to get really good at reviews and catching bugs.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to get really good at reviews and catching bugs. Of course this increased the time I spent on reviews (by about twofold) which showed me how little time I was really dedicating to this important piece of the development lifecycle. I now make it a habit to run a branch locally, walk through any and all scenarios that I can think of from a user perspective and then tweak small parts of the code that aren’t clear to me.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: small parts of the code that aren’t clear to me. Sometimes these small tweaks can reveal better ways of doing the same thing or at least make the developer’s intent more clear. Console logging and debugging my way through new logic usually gives me a pretty clear idea of what is happening and why.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a pretty clear idea of what is happening and why. If you’re newer to writing code or reviewing code that is way out of your league, I would suggest having the author walk you through any unclear portions of the changes and exactly what they are supposed to do. Hopefully the code review becomes a way to share knowledge and discuss what’s written, rather than another list item to check off.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: rather than another list item to check off. Don’t assume that the super duper gold star developer on the team won’t make the same goofball mistakes that you and the other noodle-heads on your team have 😉. ConclusionI’m sure I’ll have a host of equally embarrassing follies to share in the coming years, but hopefully you know that you’re not alone in screwing up and maybe, just maybe you can avoid some of the mistakes I’ve confessed to here.

metadata.title: My Most Embarrassing Coding Mistakes… So Far
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: So You Want to Get Paid to CodeIt’s as easy as for(i=0; i<Infinity; i++)I’m gonna study in triple time. “Bro, I think I’m gonna go into coding,” an acquaintance recently told me. “Oh,” I replied. I’ve actually heard some variation of this statement dozens of times over the years.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of this statement dozens of times over the years. People watch Silicon Valley, maybe they’ve read some fluff article in their local paper about how an 11 year old kid built a million dollar app or how students across the nation are learning to code in the classroom and think “Can’t be that hard can it. ” All I gotta do is memorize some codes or something and then jam them out in some logical sequence right. Next step, app store fame and remote work on a beach.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: step, app store fame and remote work on a beach. Let me let you in on a little secret there, bucko, the path to coding is well paved but there are many forks on this road and a lot of endless loops, so many endless loops and… well, perhaps metaphors aren’t my forte (this is why I ended up coding and not writing great American novels) but what I’m trying to say is that learning to be a hirable front end or full stack developer will require you to be familiar with a lot of technology.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you to be familiar with a lot of technology. Here is my list of basic skills that I think are generally required to get your foot in the door. HTML + CSSI mean duh, right. You better understand HTML and CSS, the DOM (look it up if you don’t know) and how to do things like write media queries, use pseudo selectors, probably a CSS framework like Bootstrap and flexbox.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a CSS framework like Bootstrap and flexbox. Basically, if you can re-create the landing page of a popular site (not Google) using HTML and CSS and make it responsive (looks good on phone and browser) then you probably know enough HTML and CSS to be dangerous. JavascriptKnowing only HTML and CSS can actually land you a job, but not likely as a front end developer.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a job, but not likely as a front end developer. You’re going to need to know Javascript and considering that most interviews will throw some sort of algorithm style question at you, it’s in your best interest to know it well. After you get past the basics of making something happens when a button is clicked, you’ll need to dive deeper into asynchronous Javascript, closure and what the heck this means.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Javascript, closure and what the heck this means. Having some knowledge of these more advanced topics are often the key to getting past an initial phone screening. Also, they make you better at your job. The TerminalYou’ve seen those hacker movies where some guy is typing code into some black screen with green colored type. Well, that’s the command line, or the terminal.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Well, that’s the command line, or the terminal. In order to be an effective developer, you’re gonna need to know how to navigate between files using the command line and there are so many programs specifically designed to be run in the terminal that you will have to feel a confident with basic commands. If you can find a file on your desktop using the command line and print the contents of a file to the screen, I’d say you have a good foundation.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to the screen, I’d say you have a good foundation. Bonus points if you can open and then exit Vim, your native text editor in the terminal. Git and GithubWriting code professionally is a team sport and you’re going to need to know how to share your code with others.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: need to know how to share your code with others. Github is an online platform that allows people to share and edit work as well as keep track of file history and revisions which can really come in handy if you make a mistake and need to revert to a working copy or if several people will be working in the same codebase. Once you learn basic git, look into merges, solving merge conflicts and branching strategies.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: solving merge conflicts and branching strategies. This is one of those skills which will serve you well at whatever company you work for. Javascript FrameworkPick one. Go ahead, just pick one. There are 1 million and 4 articles written each day about which JS framework you should choose. Just pick one and stick with it. Maybe not Vue. Yeah I said it, sorry, but here we are. I’d say React is likely the safest bet with Angular being a close second.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the safest bet with Angular being a close second. Developers switch companies all the time and they don’t all use the same framework. What’s more important is your underlying knowledge of JS which will make you able to pick up new frameworks as they come into fashion. DatabasesLike it or not, you will be interacting with databases in some way. Perhaps you’ll be constructing the queries to fetch data or at a smaller startup you may be involved in actually creating and scaling databases.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in actually creating and scaling databases. Knowing the difference between SQL and No-SQL databases is a great start and can help you speak intelligently if an interviewer asks you what DB you might use given a specific scenario. I’ve found HackerRank to be a particular good place to learn some SQL and there many other places to try your hand at basic SQL which is ubiquitous especially among more established companies. AlgorithmsLearn some.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: more established companies. AlgorithmsLearn some. No one will expect you to be an expert at obscure algorithms, especially if you are an entry level developer but I’d bet that the majority of your interviews will involve at least one algo style interview question. Leetcode is the site of choice for most programmers as they study for Google or all the Google-wannabes and learn to invert binary trees and find the most common number in an array.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: trees and find the most common number in an array. If you can muddle your way through some of the easier questions and maybe a few of the medium level ones then I’d say you’re in good shape as an entry level candidate at a lower tier company. But Wait…There’s always more. Writing tests, deployments, system design, bagjaggery… alright, I made that last one up, but you see what I’m getting at.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that last one up, but you see what I’m getting at. To be honest, I was hired with considerably less of these skills than outlined here but had to quickly learn them to be hirable when I went on the hunt again and my journey with things like algorithms and Javascript is ongoing.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: things like algorithms and Javascript is ongoing. This no frills path is what I would consider the basics needed to be competitive so when I hear people casually saying they want to pick up code and become a developer, I just say, “Oh,” because it’s easier than spouting off this laundry list of skills. Oh, indeed.

metadata.title: So You Want to Get Paid to Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders. Pictured: simple redux flow between connected components 😫If you are a React developer working on a less than trivial project, you are likely using Redux for state management. In a crude nutshell, your connected components are all listening for any updates to the store, the global state of the app, and your mapStateToProps function takes some slice of this state and returns it as props to your connected component.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: returns it as props to your connected component. I was recently working on a strange bug at work involving a redux-connected component: a user would hover over a slice of our pie chart component and sometimes the label in the center of the pie would just revert back to the default label… hmmm. For some reason, our pie chart was re-rendering even though it’s state had not updated.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: even though it’s state had not updated. Double hmmm…This intermittent bug was difficult to reproduce, but once it was sharing the store with a widget consuming realtime socket updates, I noticed it happened each time our store received a realtime update. Should a component re-render each time the store receives an update — even if it’s not interested in that particular slice of the state. Nah, that can’t be right.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: slice of the state. Nah, that can’t be right. Then how does our mapStateToProps function understand when it should trigger a re-render. Well, under the hood, redux does a shallow comparison of the state returned from mapStateToProps by implementing the shouldComponentUpdate method. Interesting. Still doesn’t quite explain why our pie is freaking out though.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: quite explain why our pie is freaking out though. Here’s a simplified version of our pie chart code:import React from 'react';import { connect } from 'react-redux';import PieChartWidget from '. /components/PieChartWidget';const mergeProps = (stateProps, dispatchProps, ownProps) => { return {. ownProps,. dispatchProps,. stateProps};};const mapStateToProps = (state, ownProps) => { const data = state. widgetData; const apiArgs = {. ownProps. apiArgs }; //OOPS.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: const apiArgs = {. ownProps. apiArgs }; //OOPS. return { data, apiArgs };};const IssuesPieChart = ({ apiArgs, data,}) => ( <DataLoader apiArgs={apiArgs} {. others} > <PieChartWidget data={data} /> </Widget>);export default connect(mapStateToProps, mapWidgetDispatchToProps, mergeProps)(IssuesPieChart);Well, it turns out we were making an honest mistake in our mapStateToProps function, which was copying state using the spread. operator. D’oh.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: copying state using the spread. operator. D’oh. Common array operations like slice, concat, filter or. create a new reference to an object or array which will trigger a component update when redux internally compares the old and new state. The quick fix here was to simply assign our state like this:const mapStateToProps = (state, ownProps) => { const data = state. widgetData; const apiArgs = ownProps.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: = state. widgetData; const apiArgs = ownProps. apiArgs; return { data, apiArgs };};If your use case is more complicated and there is some filtering or selecting of a part of the state tree you care about, you may want to check out memoized selector functions to prevent expensive comparisons and needless re-renders: https://redux. js. org/recipes/computing-derived-data#creating-a-memoized-selectorJavaScript In Plain EnglishEnjoyed this article.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: In Plain EnglishEnjoyed this article. If so, get more similar content by subscribing to our YouTube channel.

metadata.title: Is mapStateToProps causing needless re-renders?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Being Black-ish in TechAnd this is why you shouldn’t quote rap lyrics during team meetings…Being a half-Black dude from Oakland who didn’t grow up using computers, most people I know were a little surprised to hear me switching careers at 30 to become a software engineer. Channeling my addictive personality to study code and write loads of useless toy programs and horrific sites served me well and I studied myself into a job through persistence and some luck 😉.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: into a job through persistence and some luck 😉. Growing up as a mixed dude that looked more Latino than Black made me hyper-aware of how important race is in our daily interactions. Even today, the first thing people usually ask when they meet me is where my parents are from, or what’s your ethnicity, or what are you mixed with. Basically, what the hell are you. I’m used to it, and I’ve been privy to a lot of conversations I might not well have been if people knew my true identity.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: well have been if people knew my true identity. Like a race spy. I always knew I’d be a minority in the field of software engineering but sometimes I’m a bit surprised by just how homogenous the field is. In the last 5 years, I can count the number of Black software engineers I’ve met on one hand and still have enough left to grip a teacup. Every year, StackOverflow releases its developer survey results and I am re-shocked to learn less than 5% of professional developers surveyed are Black.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 5% of professional developers surveyed are Black. Similar disappointing results abound for women, Latinos and other non-White male groups. But who cares. Well, outside of the moral implications for denying or restricting access to upwardly mobile careers like software development to certain groups, how do companies propose to create products for our increasingly diverse world.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: products for our increasingly diverse world. Imagine a team of 14 year olds, who build a dating site that takes off but has a significant amount of users who are 50 and older. They quickly brainstorm the features this group may like and ham-handedly add an option to filter potential matches by age. The icon for this filter: an old man with a cane. Older users expectedly aren’t too keen on this and leave the app.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: aren’t too keen on this and leave the app. A lame apology is issued and people scratch their heads at how they could have possibly thought that would go over well.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: have possibly thought that would go over well. This may sound pretty far-fetched but think about recent events (I know there’s been a lot lately) like Gucci releasing their Black-face sweater, a fresh-take on old school racism, or now that the US has decided to care about Black people for a bit, how many companies have been falling over themselves to show how un-racist they are before they incur the wrath of a newly woke public.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: they incur the wrath of a newly woke public. Being racist isn’t just bad for your soul (as its always been) it’s probably bad for your business too. It makes logical sense that teams with a diverse array of thought, experiences and talents are exactly what is needed to foster innovation as well as better reflect diverse end-user populations. Black Twitter anyone. There just aren’t enough (insert coveted minority here) candidatesI know, I know.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: coveted minority here) candidatesI know, I know. Your company combed over 1,649 resumes and only found a handful of “diverse” candidates. I mean, you can’t just pick them out of thin air. Or maybe you can…Larger companies absolutely have the power to create internship to job programs where they can aggressively target all those groups which aren’t currently represented on their teams. Give people who may not have all the checkboxes ticked off on their resumes a chance to learn on the job.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: off on their resumes a chance to learn on the job. Have your senior engineers mentor these incoming prospects and then fold them into your organization if/when they are ready.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: into your organization if/when they are ready. At those even larger companies, planting some seeds in the local school system by offering free workshops, funding STEM programs and perhaps high school internships could dramatically reshape the landscape of your workforce and offer some opportunities to people who might not have even know that a career as a software engineer is within their reach.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: as a software engineer is within their reach. Heck, if I had know more about this a young lad, I wouldn’t have waited until I was 30 with 2 kids to begin writing code. Cautiously optimisticWhile White America has seemingly just found out about this thing called racism, for the majority of POC, race is an inescapable factor that colors so much of our day we don’t even notice it… or at least, we’ve come to accept it.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: notice it… or at least, we’ve come to accept it. We wonder if our colleagues respect us or think we are a charity case to increase diversity, we see all White C-Levels and don’t think twice, we get asked to show our badge a little more than others and when off-color jokes about rap music or Black culture get made pre-meeting we sit uncomfortably and hope no one impersonates Cardi B.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and hope no one impersonates Cardi B. As tech companies in particular continue to be some of the most vocal advocates of diversity, it’d be nice to see this commitment translate into a workforce that looks more like their user bases and the communities that they call home.

metadata.title: Being Black-ish in Tech
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I've spent a lot of time trying to get better at code reviews and I agree with all the points here. It's one of those skills I just didn't see much value in until an embarrassing bug slipped by me - then I vowed I would become a much better bug catcher. Nice article.

metadata.title: I've spent a lot of time trying to get better at code reviews and I agree with all the points here!
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The Unspoken Rules of Software TeamsOn Tuesdays we add the bugs…You may think that being on a software team mostly involves writing code. While that’s not exactly wrong, there is a lot of nuance, expected behavior and implied knowledge that comes along with the job and picking up on these unspoken rules can be just as important as your company’s mission to create the AirBnB of children’s tree houses or the DoorDash for embarrassing medicine prescriptions or whatever.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: embarrassing medicine prescriptions or whatever. During my first year as a developer, I had to make a mental shift in order to get used to the culture of working in software. Luckily, I had a very understanding team that did a lot of hand-holding and explicitly laid out some of the most obvious expectations for me like what happens during daily stand up or the process for doing code reviews but much of what I picked up during that first year isn’t taught in any bootcamp or class.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: first year isn’t taught in any bootcamp or class. When Do I Ask For Help. As a noob to the software world, this is one of the most pervasive questions I hear from people about to start their first day. Now, every (good) team will encourage questions from new hires in order to help them ramp up, but there is a limit to your team’s patience and you’ll find some members more agreeable than others to lend a hand.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: members more agreeable than others to lend a hand. My rule of thumb (that I sometimes struggle to follow) is that if I haven’t made much progress in an hour of struggling through an issue, I will alert either the entire team via a shared channel on Slack or DM someone that is familiar with the issue at hand. I figure, if you’re getting paid to write code, you don’t want to spend 8 hours fumbling around when a co-worker can get you on track in a few minutes of time.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: can get you on track in a few minutes of time. Conversely, disrupting co-workers in the middle of a difficult task before doing any Googling will make you a burden on some unlucky person and no one wants that. Also, add details to those issues you’re stuck on: how to reproduce the problem, any error messages, and any other relevant details which reduce the cognitive load on your partner. Lastly, when someone has earphones on, it’s best to tread with caution.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: has earphones on, it’s best to tread with caution. This is usually a signal that they are trying to focus. This is why I like to ask questions via a team channel and that way people can share asynchronous feedback or offer help at their convenience. Detach Yourself from Code ReviewsMy first, second, third, hell, my tenth code review stung to read. My ego was bruised, look at all these suggestions, I thought to myself.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: at all these suggestions, I thought to myself. And to top it off, they’re written so matter-of-factly: “this doesn’t make sense here”, “is this necessary. ”, “re-write to make more DRY. ” Without the benefit of hearing a voice behind code review comments, they can often sound deflating or at worst, downright mean.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: often sound deflating or at worst, downright mean. It’s taken me a while to shake the jitters from receiving particularly critical reviews but although writing code can feel like writing a novel for some people, your work of art is mostly functional and good code reviews can help you level up your skills as well as make the code just work better, which is the ultimate goal. It’s usually best to look at your code as more of a surgical procedure rather than a creative masterpiece.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: procedure rather than a creative masterpiece. While your first reviews may feel a bit jarring, also take time to really understand what the reviewer is asking and if your team is any good, the review should be less of a laundry list of tasks and more of a conversation. Instead of “this doesn’t work as expected” — try “have you considered doing x or y instead of your current approach — let me know what you think.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: current approach — let me know what you think. ” Even if your team doesn’t follow this approach — I personally think creating more conversational reviews is a great way to positively influence the engineering culture. CommentsAll that code you wrote in the comfort of your own home probably had like, 1 contributor: you. Now here you are on a team of more than 1 pushing and pulling things to GitHub and touching codebases larger than you realized could exist.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: codebases larger than you realized could exist. This is the time to make sure your communication via comments is helpful to those that come after you. I’ve heard some people say that good code should be self-documenting and while I agree that an over-reliance on comments is a code-smell (something that points to a deeper problem) I feel that certain pieces of code that either break some convention or are not completely obvious need to be explicitly called out through comments.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: need to be explicitly called out through comments. It’s happened more than once where I’ve stared at a piece of code which I’m ready to refactor only to go down the rabbit hole and find that in 1998 some dev wrote it because it stops an obscure bug from happening when Daylight Savings time goes into effect. Go figure. Speaking of comments, your PR requests in GitHub should always have some description of what you’ve done.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: always have some description of what you’ve done. It’s frustrating getting a PR with several files changed and no word on what is supposed to be happening. Now I’m the detective in a mystery where I’m not sure what crime has been committed. It’s So Quiet Over HereSoftware teams are quiet. Oddly, this is the thing that tripped me out the most when I began working as a dev.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: me out the most when I began working as a dev. Every company I’ve gone to has been largely the same: the place where the devs are located is always much quieter than the rest of the office. The sales people are schmoozing it up over the phone and usually amongst one another, the product people are having lunch and talking over some designs or maybe playing a game, and the devs, well, they have their earphones on, staring intently at their double monitors.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on, staring intently at their double monitors. This is of course a bit of a generalization but after working for a few companies and interviewing at even more, this stereotype seems to hold some weight. There’s nothing wrong with the quietness, in fact, it makes sense considering devs are likely solving problems which require a lot of concentration but if you are coming from a career outside of tech, this may surprise you.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a career outside of tech, this may surprise you. <Insert Weirdly Specific Company Policy Here>I’ve listed a few of the most common unspoken rules that you will see dev teams follow but every company has it’s own twist on engineering culture and the quicker you understand it, the faster you will be able to integrate into the team and focus on what’s really important — making the next Zillow for taco trucks or whatever.

metadata.title: The Unspoken Rules of Software Teams
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Writing Defensive JavaScriptYou hear a lot of programmers joke about JavaScript not being a “real” programming language. Besides not having a Class based system of inheritance, JS is also dynamically typed unlike C#, Java, Scala… you know, all those real programming languages. But the speed, flexibility and ease of use are what led us to write JS. Types be damned.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: use are what led us to write JS. Types be damned. Of course there is a cost to the flexibility that JS offers, some of which may be negated if you’re using Typescript, but using the following defense tactics while writing code can save you a pesky bug down the road (that also rhymes so you know it’s true 😉).

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: road (that also rhymes so you know it’s true 😉). Use Default ParamsIf you have a function which depends on an argument being present and being of a certain type then you should consider using default parameters in your function’s signature. const addNameToNameArray = (name, nameArray) => { if(name. length){ nameArray. push(name) } return nameArray}Simple enough right. We take a name and a name array and then simply add the name to the array if one is present.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: add the name to the array if one is present. We are making some assumptions here however that the name will be of a type that has a length property and that our nameArray will be, well, an array. If either one of these conditions is not met, we will fail spectacularly. const addNameToNameArray = (name = '', nameArray = []) => { if(name. length){ nameArray. push(name) } return nameArray}Ahh, much better.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: push(name) } return nameArray}Ahh, much better. Now we can sleep at night, knowing this useless function won’t break production once it’s deployed if it’s called with a missing argument. Using An Object as an ArgumentYour team had this nice little function that accepted 3 arguments and did some straightforward logic with it to fetch some data from a third party service. But that was the past, now this little function is nearly unrecognizable and has a whopping 6 arguments getting passed to it.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: has a whopping 6 arguments getting passed to it. Now, usually an argument with more than, I don’t know, let’s say 3 arguments would be a code smell, but there are times you can’t avoid it. const createUser = (name, date, profileId, dataId, dataType, apiKey) => { const user = { name, profileId }; const formattedDate = moment(date). unix(); thirdPartyAPI.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: = moment(date). unix(); thirdPartyAPI. fetch(user, formattedDate, dataId, dataType, apiKey)}createUser('Bob', '04/20/20', 1, 123, 1234, 'story', 'abc123')The danger in functions like these are that the order of the arguments matters and if any of them are incorrect, we risk blowing up our API call. More arguments, means more surface area to make mistakes.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: means more surface area to make mistakes. It’s nearly inevitable that some developer will call this function and the profileId will be in the place of the dataId. Now this won’t blow up your program as they are both likely numbers or strings, but their incorrect order will give you the wrong data from the API or worse, just not work. const createUser = ({name, date, profileId, dataId, dataType, apiKey}) => { const user = { name, profileId };const formattedDate = moment(date).

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: profileId };const formattedDate = moment(date). unix(); thirdPartyAPI. fetch(user, formattedDate, dataId, dataType, apiKey)}createUser({ name: 'Bob', date: '04/20/20', profileId: 1, dataId: 123, dataType: 'story' apiKey: '123abc'})Boom. Using an object, we actually place less cognitive load on our fellow developers and make sure that our arguments are explicitly set. For functions with more than 4 arguments, I feel like using an object is a must.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: arguments, I feel like using an object is a must. Optional ChainingWe deal a lot with objects in JavaScript. Many people famously, and wrongly, say that everything in JavaScript is an object. Well, that’s not quite true, but we do end up working with them and their properties often and digging out the useful info can be a pain and a bit dangerous if you’re not careful. const hat = user. outfit. hat;Harmless right.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: const hat = user. outfit. hat;Harmless right. Well, if our user object doesn’t have an outfit property or that property is undefined then we will have an issue on our hands. TypeError: Cannot read property 'hat' of undefinedNow, the first step in making sure we don’t get this error is to check at each level whether the next property exists, and we get stuck writing unsexy code like thisconst hat = user && user. outfit && user. outfit.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: && user. outfit && user. outfit. hat || 'hat';We feel a little sad writing this and a whole hell of a lot less sexy. Thankfully, with the power of Babel, JS developers can take advantage of what Ruby and Coffeescript developers have had for years: optional chainingconst hat = user. outfit. hat || 'hat'Mmmmm, satisfying. Now if our traversal fails at any point, our operation will short-circuit and return undefined. The code is both safer and more readable.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The code is both safer and more readable. The Best Offense is Good DefenseTo me, a lot of writing defensive JavaScript is simply putting up logical safeguards to protect your code from input you might not expect, but will accept. Hopefully some of these suggestions will prevent you from being woken up at 3am on a Saturday morning to fix a bug in production.

metadata.title: Writing Defensive Javascript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain ConsistencyAs a full stack or front end JS developer, you’re going to find yourself spending a lot of time dealing with objects returned from an API that you will need to format to an interface that your front end expects.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to an interface that your front end expects. Maybe you are using a third party API that returns JSON data in kebab_case or has dates that are in some godawful format or proper names that aren’t capitalized, or maybe your backend team has recently updated the database to use new field names or changed old values to a new format.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: field names or changed old values to a new format. Now you have the choice of updating all your front end code which relies on legacy naming conventions and expects certain values or having your API maintain consistency by formatting the data before passing it off to the front end… I’ll choose working with the API over the error prone method of updating all my front end code any day.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: method of updating all my front end code any day. You always have the option of rolling your own formatter function which can take in an object and return its new and improved version. This will likely involve deleting keys, reassigning properties as well as helper functions to transform the object values. Rolling your own has the benefit of giving you granular control but comes with the cost of maintaining the logic and testing the functionality.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the logic and testing the functionality. Luckily there’s a simple library which handles this common task of transforming object values and keys: object-mapper. This package makes formatting an array of objects pretty trivial:First let’s install the package — npm install object-mapperconst mapper = require('object-mapper')//our mapper const map = { "created_at": { //old key key: "createdAt", //the key we want to use transform: (val) => { return new Date(val).

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: use transform: (val) => { return new Date(val). toString() } }, "user_name": { key: "userName", transform: (val) => { return `${val[0]. toUpperCase()}${val.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: => { return `${val[0]. toUpperCase()}${val. slice(1)}`; } }, "story_body": "storyBody"};//our raw dataconst data = [ { created_at: '12/25/2019', user_name: 'alex', story_body: 'random story' }, { created_at: '12/28/2019', user_name: 'jimbo', story_body: 'another random story' }];//lets transform the dataconst transformedData = data.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: transform the dataconst transformedData = data. map((datum) => mapper(datum, map))//outcome[ { createdAt: 'Wed Dec 25 2019 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time)', userName: 'Alex', storyBody: 'random story' }, { createdAt: 'Sat Dec 28 2019 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time)', userName: 'Jimbo', storyBody: 'another random story' }]Our map in the code above is an object in which the keys are the properties of the object we wish to transform.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the properties of the object we wish to transform. The key and transform properties tell our mapper the new name of the object’s key and how we will transform the value of the object passed in, respectively. Now we simply pass our map to the mapper library with the object we want transformed and voila. Our new and improved object has proper name casing, properties that match the JS naming convention and a real date instead of a string.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: convention and a real date instead of a string. So next time your database schema changes or you switch data providers, you may want to consider object-mapper as a means to keep your front-end happy and maintain data sanity.

metadata.title: Using object-mapper to Format Your API Data and Maintain Consistency
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should AskSo you say you know Javascript hotshot— how bout you implement Djikstra’s algorithm using Typescript. Ok — so I’ve done quite a few interviews over the years, probably at least 20 in all. I’ve also interviewed about a dozen candidates during this time as well and I hate to admit, I’ve fallen in the trap of asking the same basic flavor of Javascript questions I’ve been asked.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: flavor of Javascript questions I’ve been asked. I think Kyle Simpson probably dies a little bit inside each time I’ve asked a candidate to find the duplicate in an array 🤦‍♂. Some questions have been posed so often they become trite: finding a duplicate, FizzBuzz, 3sum, 2sum etc. These toy problems can offer some insight into how a candidate approaches a problem but more often than not, they really just show how much time that person has dedicated to studying Leetcode.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that person has dedicated to studying Leetcode. To be fair, there are some times you’ll need to traverse a tree-like structure or think of an efficient way to store data with constant time look up. I also think that studying data structures and common algorithms is an excellent trait and shows dedication and willingness to learn which are qualities most engineering teams want their members to possess.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: engineering teams want their members to possess. But let’s get real for a minute here — your day to day work as a JS dev is going to involve a lot less Djikstra and a whole lot more npm installWhat are these tests really looking to ascertain. That the candidate will know enough JS to successfully engage with your codebase. What level is their mastery of Javascript as a whole (do they understand closure, inheritance, functional programming).

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: closure, inheritance, functional programming). or is it to see how well they can communicate their thought process under the awkward circumstance of being in a room with strangers. Maybe some combination of all the above.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Maybe some combination of all the above. Whether it’s Google, Facebook or your company, which probably thinks it is the next Google or Facebook — I’ve seen questions posed during interviews that boil down to being clever with JS while understanding common CS fundamentals or worse, obscure JS concepts that you could easily look up (what happens if you run isNaN === isNaN ). There’s got to be a better way.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: isNaN === isNaN ). There’s got to be a better way. To get a general sense of how well a person understand’s JS and also how they will approach building something, I think the following questions are a much better indicator of how well someone will do on your typical front-end focused team:Using only HTML, CSS and JS, display this array of data on the screen, paginated so only 10 items are visible at a time.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: paginated so only 10 items are visible at a time. Let’s make a chart using some library you’ve never used (HighCharts, Victory or D3 if you want to be a jerk) — add some click events if time allows. For React-centered roles, refactor this class based component using lifecycle methods like componentDidMount or componentDidUnmount to a functional component using hooksMerge these two arrays of objects by matching them another object with the same id://data 1[ { id: 1, val: 100 },.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: with the same id://data 1[ { id: 1, val: 100 },. ]//data 2[ { id: 1, name: 'Entity 1' },. ]//result[ { id: 1, val: 100, name: 'Entity 1' },. ]5. Here’s a third party API with a key — create a UI to consume the data from this UI and make it look like this (*shows picture of simple UI to candidate)Obviously these suggestions won’t work for all JS developer roles.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: suggestions won’t work for all JS developer roles. Perhaps you really do need someone with strong CS fundamentals and expert level understanding of Typescript or some obscure JS framework like Vue 😉 because they will be your first engineering hire or building the initial product using this technology.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the initial product using this technology. More often than not however, I think challenges based in real world scenarios offer a much better insight to coding ability than if the person can invert a binary tree… though that is impressive as well.

metadata.title: The Javascript Interview Questions They Should Ask
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Stop Being Afraid of LeetcodeChances are if you attended a coding bootcamp or are self-taught, your impostor syndrome flares up when someone mentions algorithms, run-time complexity or references some well known algorithm that you’ve never heard of… am I supposed to know this stuff, you wonder.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of… am I supposed to know this stuff, you wonder. Bootcamps are great (sometimes) at getting grads ready to for the workforce and typical developer tasks via front-end-centric projects and curriculum which often comes at the expense of learning common algorithms. I’ll never forget when I joined a startup some years ago and we were discussing potentially trying to optimize routes for truckers who were delivering cargo.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: routes for truckers who were delivering cargo. One of the senior engineers made a joke about the Traveling Salesman problem and everyone laughed, including me, even though I had no clue what the hell they were talking about.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: had no clue what the hell they were talking about. So then he’s like let’s use bubble sort to decrease runtime complexity…While most software developers will admit it’s fairly rare to re-implement common algorithms for sorting and searching or dreaded graph problems, learning them can only deepen your skillset and give you an appreciation for these algorithms which we leverage everyday.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for these algorithms which we leverage everyday. If you’re not really into learning for the sake of learning, then maybe the promise of money will give you the inspiration you need to study. If you’re planning on interviewing with any of the top (or even mid-level) tech companies and getting one of those coveted salaries you’re hoping will fill a void in your life with Teslas and AllBirds then you need to make Leetcode your friend.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: then you need to make Leetcode your friend. Leetcode can be intimidating initially as you’re likely encountering problems that you’ve never come across in the course of your daily work and getting a solution, even a sub-optimal one can eat up hours of your time. At least at first. I’ve come to approach Leetcode in the same way I view exercising — a necessary habit, whose benefits aren’t always immediately apparent.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: whose benefits aren’t always immediately apparent. The secret to getting good at Leetcode, is the same “secret” that will make you good at anything: consistency. Yeah, not the sexy answer you were looking for perhaps, but it’s the truth Ruth. Once you finish a nice variety of problems, research the answers and check out discussions, you will find patterns that emerge. Here’s my checklist for attacking a Leetcode problem:Pick a question that is at the limit of your current knowledge.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that is at the limit of your current knowledge. It won’t help you much to solve something that you’re totally familiar with. Thoroughly understand the problem you’re trying to solve and look at the example inputs and outputs before writing anything. Think through an approach, even a very naive, suboptimal one and begin coding the pieces you understand. Resist the urge to Google the question but instead Google the specific area you are having trouble with.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the specific area you are having trouble with. In the example above, I needed to remind myself how to get the first element from an array and also the syntax used to get the remainder from division. Once you have something resembling a solution, run that bad boy and see what the outcome is. Ok, it was wrong, for like the 20th time. At some point, you will have exhausted your mental capacity.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you will have exhausted your mental capacity. Sometimes, after a night of sleep, I will wake up with a solution I didn’t consider in my previous attempts. Sometimes I won’t. This is when it’s time to check out the discussion of the question or peruse Medium for an article exploring the solution — that’s right, there are small articles written for almost every Leetcode question that is out there. Don’t copy and paste the solution.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is out there. Don’t copy and paste the solution. In fact, your goal should be to understand the problem just well enough that you can still craft your own solution, with some peeking at the solution you looked up in the previous step.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the solution you looked up in the previous step. After enough Leetcoding and researching all those problems that stop you in your tracks, you should begin to see a pattern of approaches that are used to solve a variety of problems: depth first search, breadth first search, binary search, sliding window…Repeat 1–7 often.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: binary search, sliding window…Repeat 1–7 often. While there are some people that live and die by Leetcode, I still believe it’s not necessarily the most effective tool to become a better developer but it is a necessity to get into top tier companies (for the most part), will make you better at problem solving and at the very least will allow you to get all the nerdy jokes your fellow developers make.

metadata.title: Stop Being Afraid of Leetcode
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software EngineerMe on my first on-call rotation — “Everything is fine, everything is fine”I had been a software engineer at my last company for about a month when my manager let me know I’d be going on-call during the next rotation. “Cool” I replied. Not cool. I installed PagerDuty, a popular app that is as necessary as it is hated, to alert me when any critical ticket was created.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to alert me when any critical ticket was created. I had casually been keeping tabs on the kinds of bugs that were deemed critical to see what I could expect during my shift. Basically, anything that prevented our customers from normal usage of any one of our many applications would trigger an alert. Button to export a CSV is broken. Critical ticket. API returning 500’s on a Saturday at 2 a. m. Extra critical ticket.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on a Saturday at 2 a. m. Extra critical ticket. Now, we had a comprehensive test suite, incredibly high test coverage and a kick ass QA team but I had yet to see a week go by without at least two critical escalations. At my previous companies, critical tickets were few and far between, and as such, there wasn’t much formality around how to handle these show-stopping bugs.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: around how to handle these show-stopping bugs. At one company, the rotation would change every day and on the weekends, if anything blew up, we would play the game of who is going to acknowledge this first. Not it. Luckily, my new company had some decent protocols in place for handling on-call rotation, though this didn’t lessen my stress. If you are a new software engineer and nearing or currently handling your first on-call, you’re likely feeling that same anxiety. Don’t worry… too much.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: feeling that same anxiety. Don’t worry… too much. You Won’t Know How to Fix EverythingAnd you shouldn’t. If the product you’re working on has any sort of complexity, there is a strong likelihood that you won’t know how to fix a bug in a part of the system you’ve never seen. Only Bob, the super-senior alpha-geek knows how that exact program works. He’s out on vacation of course.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: program works. He’s out on vacation of course. Hopefully, your team is aware that you are a human and thus fallible, and will reach out when they see you dealing with a bug that is particularly difficult to find and squash. If they don’t, you need to raise your hand, no matter how uncomfortable and ask for help. Pairing with another developer can improve your knowledge of the codebase and perhaps theirs as well.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of the codebase and perhaps theirs as well. The end goal is that the bug is resolved in a timely manner, not that you learn an entirely new system while under duress. Really difficult bugs should be documented and brought up to the team to avoid them later and common issues that everyone just “knows” how to fix should be written up as step by step instructions. This way anyone can potentially jump in and fix the issue. Spread the love. We Need That Fix 1 Hour AgoEverything is on fire.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: We Need That Fix 1 Hour AgoEverything is on fire. There is a critical demo going on for a a critical client and a critical piece of the application is not working as expected. CRITICAL. The VP pings you in a public slack channel: “We need this fixed ASAP — what’s the ETA on this bug. ” — Holy smokes, the VP never pings you. You type, then delete, then type again, wondering how to politely say you have no freakin’ clue.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: how to politely say you have no freakin’ clue. Any reasonable person who has ever written less than trivial code, will understand that fixing a production bug can offer a vast array of possibilities: maybe there was a bad merge, maybe a dev misspelled a variable, maybe this thing has been broken forever and no one noticed until now. Often a bug can be thoroughly squashed with a quick fix, but other times it can lead to a full refactor on a piece of your app.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: lead to a full refactor on a piece of your app. Either way, getting to the root of the problem alone can eat up an hour’s worth of time. The key to trying to keep everyone happy is to give estimates and updates early and often. The exploratory phase should hopefully take around ~1hr and a general estimation can be made from there for how long it will take to fix, test and release to production.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: will take to fix, test and release to production. Just because someone is screaming they need this bug fixed by 3pm does not in fact mean that it will be and giving false hope is objectively worse than a frank assessment of how screwed you may be. So you see right here, this is how fucked we areKeeping all interested parties aware of what’s going on and when/if they can expect a resolution may lead to some grumbling, but any decent manager should back you up if your estimates are reasonable.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: back you up if your estimates are reasonable. It Was QA/Developer/Reviewer’s FaultI almost feel like this should go without saying but yeah, don’t point the finger at someone or publicly shame them for creating a bug. You’re right, how did that code with a glaring mistake get past tests, a reviewer and QA. Again, we’re all human, even the super senior alpha geek and sometimes we get complacent or careless or plain don’t test some scenario we should have.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: or plain don’t test some scenario we should have. The goal after fixing the bug is to share knowledge and help others not make the same mistake. Spread the love/knowledge, not the blame. Your team will be a much happier one if their focus is learning and growing instead of avoiding writing sexy, dynamic code out of fear of creating a critical ticket.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: code out of fear of creating a critical ticket. It Doesn’t Have to Suck… Too BadYour on-call may have you awake at 12am fixing a production bug or chilling out watching Udemy tutorials, but it will likely fall somewhere in between. Every team is different and the level of bugs you encounter will be routinely unpredictable. Like all good things, it will come to an end and after your trial by fire, you’ll hopefully walk away a better developer.

metadata.title: How to Survive Your First On-Call Rotation as a Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software EngineersStrap on your helmet kid, this is gonna be a rough reviewOur team lead sent me a slack one afternoon after a particularly rough epic release. Nothing had gone according to plan and we were all thoroughly chewed out during the demo of these new features. I actually had nothing to do with this particular epic, save for a simple code review. This was a problem.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: save for a simple code review. This was a problem. “Hey, I noticed you reviewed this story for the epic” the team lead wrote. Ruh roh. Here I thought I was a blameless bystander in the code disaster but the more he asked me about my review, the more of an active role I could see I had played in this tragic story. Ok, it wasn’t that dramatic, but he did walk through my review and basically asked: “How did you miss this stuff.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and basically asked: “How did you miss this stuff. ” One of the buttons had the wrong text, and when clicked had some unexpected side effects which weren’t show stopping but undesirable nonetheless. Clicking into a modal led to the wrong page. Hmmm, how did I let all these things get by me. I resolved from that moment to get better at code reviews and avoid having something that embarrassing from happening again.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: something that embarrassing from happening again. If a bug slipped through on my watch, I wanted to confidently say I had checked all the scenarios I could think of and given a thorough review. Luckily I had a couple team members who stood out as reviewers that I could learn from. What made them so gotdamn good at code reviews. TimeMaybe you’re knee deep in a complex ticket with the clock ticking against you.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: complex ticket with the clock ticking against you. Perhaps your co-worker needs this review done immediately because they want to release it for a hot-fix. Oh, Sarah did this ticket. She’s like the best coder I’ve ever met, I’m sure this is correct. Sound the buzzer — you’re about to foul out on this code review. When time is of the essence, it’s even more important to review the code thoroughly.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: even more important to review the code thoroughly. Without good reviews, code eventually devolves, decays and can become barely usable or things just slip by you that eventually get released only to cause stress-inducing hot-fixes on Friday afternoons. Yes code reviews take time, but you know what takes more time. Massive refactors, rewrites and writing spaghetti-code under duress. This same argument can be applied towards tests.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: This same argument can be applied towards tests. You say you don’t have time to test/review which means it’s even more important to make time to test and review. Code Looks FineThis ticket is pretty simple, I’ll just peruse the code real quick and look for any glaring errors. I’m embarrassed to admit this is how I did most of the code reviews early in my career. I mean, they call it a “code” review and testing things in the browser is QA’s job… right.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: testing things in the browser is QA’s job… right. I noticed the best reviewers on my team would often reject my ticket before even looking at the code. They were doing their own version of QA before inspecting my awful naming conventions or pointing out that I’d left a profanity filled comment on line 76. Why check out the code if the feature doesn’t work. Testing in the browser should be rough, with no holds barred.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the browser should be rough, with no holds barred. Console open, checking for warnings, errors or any indication that something may be awry even if the expected result is achieved. Only then should the code be reviewed. Feature Works FineThe inverse of the mistake above is to only check the browser and just gloss over the code. The review you are writing should ideally be a conversation between you and the other developer.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: conversation between you and the other developer. If something looks like it could be done better style-wise or to increase efficiency then it should be done. Failing to highlight areas to DRY up code and follow general as well as team specific best practices eventually lead to brittle, lame code and technical debt which will slowly strangle progress. Just Do This“Do this” my reviewer wrote in response to a poorly written function I had scribed. Umm, ok, cool. But why. Writing is a funny thing.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Umm, ok, cool. But why. Writing is a funny thing. That comment you put on your reviewee’s PR doesn’t have the benefit of your cheery voice or the ability to flesh out your monosyllabic demands. Give your reviewee some respect dammit. If something should be changed, offer a suggestion, perhaps a link to an article or site that supports your position and maybe even a code snippet if you feel so inclined. All your comments don’t need to offer criticism or advice.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: comments don’t need to offer criticism or advice. If there is something your reviewee did well, point that out. Especially if they have a lot of refactoring to do 😉. Now, Just Do ItBeing a valuable member on a software team isn’t always about who can write the most elegant code or crank through tickets at break-neck speed.

metadata.title: Write Better Code Reviews and Make You and Your Team Better Software Engineers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: code or crank through tickets at break-neck speed. I never prided myself on being a detail oriented person but code reviews helped me acquire more of this trait than I previously had and also sparked a lot of great discussions with team members I might not normally interact with. Forget the excuses, set aside time and watch how much your team can improve if everyone respects the art of the review.
