content: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold ComponentsPictured: Charles, React Developer at a typical day at workCharles, a ReactJS developer, sits down and wipes the breakfast burrito crumbs from his scraggly beard. “Ahh, time to create another component. ” he exclaims, while cracking his fingers and then resting them ever so gently on his mechanical keyboard. The codebase he’s adding to has a number of other components, similar to the one he’s about to create.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: similar to the one he’s about to create. He copies all the folders and files under SomeGenericComponent and renames them, then goes through the SomeGenericComponent. test. js file and updates the name of the component and removes all the current test statements. “I’ll get to these later” he chuckles. He follows a similar process for the rest of the files, changing names, removing logic and extraneous imports until he has a blank slate.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and extraneous imports until he has a blank slate. This manual process, one he’s done dozens of times, is fraught with small errors. A spelling mistake here makes an import unresolvable. An additional file that should’ve been deleted is pushed to source code. A test description is incorrect. This error-prone method that Charlie uses led our team to explore how to programatically scaffold new components and enforce established patterns and file structure without precarious copying and pasting.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: structure without precarious copying and pasting. We ultimately decided to leverage plop. js — a library for generating code. Through a plopFile we were able to expose generators to scaffold components based on the input from a user. We have a pretty useful generator here that will scaffold a component with a generic test and even includes some pieces of the global state from our redux store. Plop.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of the global state from our redux store. Plop. js has some excellent documentation for how to set up generators and template files using handlebars but one thing missing from their documentation is how to expose your generators through a standalone library. Our generator worked great when it was included in the project where we were using it but in order to leverage this tool across our different projects we needed to package this code in a library that could be installed anywhere.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in a library that could be installed anywhere. Node-plop is likely more suited for this kind of task but using it would require a lot more effort and tooling which we wanted to avoid if necessary. We published our generator library but when we linked it to a front end consumer we saw that it was not working as expected — plop looks for templates in certain directories to use based on your generator, but they were all incorrect.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on your generator, but they were all incorrect. Instead of adding the generated code to our consumer it was looking for paths that did not exist. Our solution was to use the relative paths in order to find the templates that shipped with our library and to use the current working directory to know where to install the code generated from the templates:In our consuming front ends we installed plop as a dependency and included a plopFile.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: plop as a dependency and included a plopFile. js at the root of the project where we simply required our library:Using plop is simple and can really reduce the amount of hours your team spends re-writing the same code while also enforcing standards and patterns across repos. Solving the issue of how to package and publish a library where all our templates live was the biggest hurdle we needed to clear in order to get the maximum benefit from this tool.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: order to get the maximum benefit from this tool. Hopefully a Google search led you here and saved you from re-inventing the wheel. Happy coding.

metadata.title: Publishing a Library Using PlopJS to Scaffold Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software DeveloperI was teaching at a coding bootcamp a few years ago. The class was not going well and one student, in particular, was derailing our lesson. After class, this student approached me. “You know, this stuff is hard. You’re teaching way too fast for me to keep up. This stuff might be easy for you but we didn’t all grow up using computers or learning to code.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: all grow up using computers or learning to code. ”I was a bit stunned and apologized, assuring him we could work outside of class to get him caught up. I was also flattered. My transformation was finally complete. He saw me for what I had trying so hard to look like for years…. a real software developer. 9 years ago, no one would have believed that I’d be writing code for a living, let alone managing and mentoring other engineers. Back then my life was a complete and utter mess.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Back then my life was a complete and utter mess. For the majority of my 20’s, I sold drugs. Weed, blow, meth, ecstasy and whatever else I could get my hands on. I was decent at it too. I made enough money to pay my rent, drink every night and support my own cocaine habit I’d picked up when I was 16. Eventually, my drinking and snorting spun out of control. I was getting sloppy and taking risks I shouldn’t have. I was robbed twice at gunpoint and almost lost my life.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: robbed twice at gunpoint and almost lost my life. The same guy who robbed me killed a man the next week after my robbery. I was barely sleeping, going days at a time getting high on meth and blowing then drinking to slow my racing heart down. I was taking drugs like coffee — as soon I woke up, I’d blow a line or pour a drink. At this rate, I was going to die of a heart attack or get killed in the streets.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of a heart attack or get killed in the streets. My girlfriend worked during the day so the magnitude of my addiction may not have been clear to her and I spent most of my time doing “business” anyways. I came home one night, wired up and a bit drunk. She was pregnant. This is the part where I turn my life around, I thought. Just like in the movies. If this new baby didn’t get me to change, then nothing will. I vowed to stop drinking and doing drugs… then the morning came.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: drinking and doing drugs… then the morning came. I had enough blow to kill a small horse in my cabinet at the house where I conducted my business. I thought about flushing it down the toilet. I would stop, I told myself, just after this last line. 9 months later my son was born and I was still finishing that last line. In that year I was able to get a job at a local community college with a lot of help from a friend who worked there.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: with a lot of help from a friend who worked there. I had mostly left the drug dealing phase of my life but there was never more than a day that would go by that I wouldn’t imbibe. My dealing was mostly relegated to small deals here and there to supplement my income and support my habit. I likely would have continued this hamster wheel of drinking, drugs and petty dealing until I died or was arrested. The inevitable end was getting closer and I could feel it.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: end was getting closer and I could feel it. The police in the area knew who I was and I’d been lucky enough to escape once during a traffic stop. I had old dealers calling my phone, threatening to kill me for deals I’d set up that had gone wrong. I was having panic attacks every day… literally. If the cops or the streets didn’t catch up with me my heart would. Then, something happened. 9 years ago, on Easter Sunday I stumbled into my house drunk and still high from the night before.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: house drunk and still high from the night before. I was walking back home after getting into a small car accident with my friend who had driven over a median in the road and popped all his tires. I hadn’t slept in 24 hours and made my way to the bed to pass out if my heart would stop its racing. My newborn son was nearly a year old.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: its racing. My newborn son was nearly a year old. A few weeks earlier, another friend of mine had committed suicide and his brother, one of my best customers had been sentenced to prison for human trafficking for pimping. My drinking had soared to new heights during this stressful period. At my lowest point, I can remember being under a bridge near my house, smoking meth with a group of transients who lived there.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: meth with a group of transients who lived there. My mother and girlfriend were so concerned with my drinking and snorting that they got together, and unbeknownst to me, planned an intervention that Easter Sunday. My mother barged into the house moments after I fell into the bed. We walked outside and she read me a letter that contained an ultimatum: get sober or my family would leave me. I was angry. Who were they to put this on me at this time. I was grieving and stressed.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on me at this time. I was grieving and stressed. This was the worst possible time to quit. I resented them for doing this to me but I reluctantly agreed with no clue how I would stop. I didn’t drink or do drugs the next day after she read me that letter. I would just not drink for one day at a time. Each day I woke up, I made a commitment not to drink just for that day. Eventually, the days turned to a couple of months. My body had finally settled into a rhythm but the mental anguish remained.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: into a rhythm but the mental anguish remained. I dreamt about drinking a lot. I had fantasies of going back to my old life. I also had a lot more free time. Jesus, what was I supposed to do with all this time. At work, I took on more responsibility. One of my tasks was to keep our janky website updated with information around upcoming events. A particular update required an actual code change which I had no clue how to do.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: actual code change which I had no clue how to do. I called our webmaster and scheduled some time for her to visit our office and make the update. When she opened the code editor I saw what looked like a set of hieroglyphs. I was shocked that she seemed to understand what was there. What is all that. I asked. She explained that all websites use HTML and CSS under the hood to display their content and add styling. I pressed her for more information about how she knew where to go and what to type.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: about how she knew where to go and what to type. I was still in disbelief that a human could decipher this and navigate it so easily. I used the internet every day… how the hell did I not know how to do this. She told me if I wanted to learn how to build websites I could learn HTML and CSS. Why the hell, not I figured, I had plenty of time. I searched for free courses on coding and picked up HTML and CSS. Once I made something appear on the screen I was hooked. This was my new addiction.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: screen I was hooked. This was my new addiction. I spent an inordinate amount of time learning to code and it filled the hole that alcohol and drugs previously had. 9 years and a lot of studying later, I’m an Engineering Manager who’s taught at multiple bootcamps, worked at different companies, written dozens of articles and mentored lots of people. I still dream about drinking pretty often though I don’t plan on ever drinking again in my life.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I don’t plan on ever drinking again in my life. I’ve been scared to tell people about this side of my life. I’ve worked so hard to become a different person that I feared exposing my past would make people see me as less capable. Is he a risk to work with. What if he slips up again. What if a co-worker reads this. Or a potential employer. What will they think of me.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a potential employer. What will they think of me. Honestly, I still have these fears but I also know that when I was learning to code, I met a lot of great people who helped me transition my life and career and hearing their stories gave me the boost to keep going when I felt like their might not be a light at the end of the tunnel. When I hear stories of people who come out of addiction to pursue their dreams and control their demons, I can see myself in them and I feel less alone.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I can see myself in them and I feel less alone. I hope if you’re reading this and you are going through a struggle with addiction in your life, that you feel less alone too and know that there isn’t a hole you’ve dug that’s too deep to pull yourself out of. I know you can do it.

metadata.title: Coding My Way Through Sobriety: From Drug Dealing Addict to Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I really appreciate that and you're absolutely right. writing this was a reminder of just how close I was to the edge.

metadata.title: I really appreciate that and you're absolutely right...
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 StepsI’ve been staring at this code for 6 hours and still don’t get it…As a software engineer, few events are more daunting than your first day in a new role where you are introduced to a massive codebase. If you’re lucky enough to have a formal on-boarding experience, then perhaps a more senior member has walked you through the codebase, tech debt and associated gotchas with the code you will now help shepherd.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: gotchas with the code you will now help shepherd. Even so, it can be difficult navigating the patterns used, unique edge cases and how the project fits into the larger context of the business. I’ve worked with at least 6 different codebases over the past 7 years from job switching and contracting. Here is the system I use when I want to begin contributing quickly in a new codebase and gain a basic understanding of how things are working. 1.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: basic understanding of how things are working. 1. Pick An Area to Focus OnA few years ago I worked in a particularly complex codebase with several APIs written in different languages and a few other client side apps. Honestly, it was nearly a year before I had some level of comfortability with all those repos and the general data flow. If you are a UI developer, focus on the front end apps you will be working with on a daily basis.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: apps you will be working with on a daily basis. Conversely, backend devs likely won’t get much benefit from digging into the internals of a component library used in the front end. 2. Get Something to Look AtI find it much easier to reason about the logic in an app if I can actually see it in action.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in an app if I can actually see it in action. For a client side app, this process can be trivial but for an API you may quickly learn that to hit an endpoint you need particular credentials or cookies; learning that alone is valuable and moves you closer towards your goal of shallow understanding. Once the service you are exploring is running, it’s time to click around. If the app is a UI then open your browser tools and inspect the network responses and console logs.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: inspect the network responses and console logs. For a UI focused app I will typically try to understand how data flows and is persisted as this is typically where the majority of the non-trivial logic takes place. 3. Extend FunctionalityNow that you’ve got the codebase running and are able to interact with it — it’s time to break stuff. Most teams I’ve joined will have the new developers take on tickets to update some text or adjust styling.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on tickets to update some text or adjust styling. This kind of low-stakes exercise allows them to get used to the codebase and navigate around. If your team has not provided you this opportunity, you should take on the challenge yourself. Look at the homepage and change some text, if you are working on API then update the response to include some additional information. Now that you have gained some footing in this new landscape, it’s time to extend functionality.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: new landscape, it’s time to extend functionality. In the UI you could add a button that makes a call to the backend and displays the response on the screen or manipulates the DOM. For an API, you can inspect the body of the incoming request for a certain parameter and throw a 500 if it is undefined and a 200 if it is present. There is no substitute for getting your hands dirty.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is no substitute for getting your hands dirty. No amount of documentation or poring over code can truly make you feel more confident about your understanding of a new codebase. 4. Write a TestThe most efficient and effective way to really understand some functionality of a new codebase is to write a test.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of a new codebase is to write a test. If you’re lucky enough to be on a team where test coverage is high, then you can use the tests as another form of documentation to read through and understand how this component/API really works. If your team has been slacking on their test coverage, even better. This is your opportunity to learn and make a great impression on your team by contributing to the test cases.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on your team by contributing to the test cases. While starting a new test suite from scratch can be time consuming, I’ve found this is the best way to gain a deep understanding into how code works. More often than not, at least some of my assumptions are totally incorrect or there are underlying methods and helpers that I’m exposed to that I was previously unaware of. Writing a particularly comprehensive test suite can take you from noob to pro level understanding.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: can take you from noob to pro level understanding. Putting It All TogetherWaiting for your team to provide you with the correct learning opportunities or explain the gotchas throughout the codebase will only lengthen your path from confusion to understanding. Taking initiative and following some or all of the steps here will give you some much needed confidence when you join a new company as a software developer and have you ready to contribute in a meaningful way.

metadata.title: How To Navigate a New Codebase in 4 Steps
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software DeveloperYou see that error on line 134. That’s why you’re not a senior devSo you want to become a senior/staff/mid-level developer eh. Well, hopefully not all of them at the same time, but wherever you are in your career, you’re likely wondering what it will take to get to the next step. Let many authors tell it and you’ll believe that some finite number of steps or projects will land you the next title.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of steps or projects will land you the next title. It’s rarely that simple or consistent across companies. Years ago when I first began writing code, I had a goal of becoming a senior developer. I knew I had a long road to go and the path was unclear at best. What made a senior developer. Debugging skills. Project management. Git mastery. Writing excellent code. Some combination. The truth is that the expectations for a a senior developer can vary wildly from one company to another.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: can vary wildly from one company to another. I have a friend at a well known company on a team where anyone with more than one year of experience is officially titled a senior developer, while a senior software engineer at a startup may function more like a principal architect in the absence of an engineering hierarchy. Some companies have strict YOE requirements, some don’t 🤷‍♀.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: have strict YOE requirements, some don’t 🤷‍♀. The only way to define a clear path to the next level of your engineering career is to identify the skills that are needed at that level at your current company, both spoken and unspoken. Ask the people on your team who are the level you’d like to be at what it is they see as their primary responsibility and how it may differ from the previous level. How would they describe what they do and how is different than what someone at your level does.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is different than what someone at your level does. If you have a manger, you should make your goal known to them and dig into the specifics of what it will take to get you towards this goal. What areas do you need to focus on and what kinds of projects/tasks can help you gain the necessary knowledge you may be lacking. Armed with this information from both team mates and your manager, you can devise a plan of attack.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and your manager, you can devise a plan of attack. You will take on some complex project, onboard new engineers, become a git master, fix all the TODOs littering your codebase… whatever it takes to prove you can perform at the next level. That’s good. But not enough. Before you drop your burrito on the ground and furiously shake your head in frustration, just chill out.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: shake your head in frustration, just chill out. To really build your case to be a x -level developer, you need to make sure you have sufficient visibility of the work you are doing in that pursuit. That refactor of a micro-service you did last sprint which was particularly complex — let your manager know about it. Let your team know about it. Tell the world. Offer to pair with others in a public setting and volunteer for those critical bugs that others shy away from.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for those critical bugs that others shy away from. Like it or not, promotions can be as much about skill as they are about optics. It’s hard to make a case for yourself when you do work in the shadows or do all your communication over DMs or note passing.

metadata.title: X (Maybe Not So Simple) Steps to Become [Insert Title] Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Questions I Get Asked From Junior DevelopersYes I’ve been coding for years and to answer your question, No, I still don’t get CSS…After transitioning to a career in tech at 30 and with no prior programming experience, I understand how difficult making that switch can be and remember the fears and anxiety I had during that time.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the fears and anxiety I had during that time. Here are the top questions I get from people who are starting their careers as developers or thinking of looking into a career where they write code for a living:What Should I Learn. Well, it depends. If you want to be a backend developer, you should probably focus on Java, Python, Ruby, C#or whatever language/framework is in demand where you live.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: language/framework is in demand where you live. Most people that write to me are looking to become web developers so they need to learn HTML, CSS, Javascript and a Javascript framework at a minimum. Should I Go to a Bootcamp. I’ve used a few bootcamps to supplement my computer science fundamentals and have also taught at a few as well but that doesn’t mean I recommend them for everyone.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that doesn’t mean I recommend them for everyone. If you have the money, time and dedication as well as realistic expectations then I would suggest going to an immersive program that has some sort of test to get in. A bootcamp that will accept anyone is usually a sign to me that they are more interested in enrolling fleshy money machines than really getting people hired. If money/time presents a problem then I totally think you can learn yourself into a career with dedication and focus.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: yourself into a career with dedication and focus. What Framework Should I Learn. React. Maybe Angular if you don’t live on the west coast. ReactJS is the dominant framework and there is a troubling trend of companies saying they are looking for Javascript developers but really need people with ReactJS experience. If you are junior, then this expectation is even less flexible. How Can I Learn X. YouTube. Udemy. Educative. A book if you’re a maniac maybe.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Udemy. Educative. A book if you’re a maniac maybe. My point is that there are a ton of free and not-so-free resources out there for people to use to learn how to compose software and websites. The main benefit that a bootcamp or mentor can provide is that they give you a very clear path of what to learn. With so many free resources it can be easy to get paralyzed by choice or end up in a loop of never ending tutorials. Don’t do this.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a loop of never ending tutorials. Don’t do this. There is absolutely no substitute for putting finger to keyboard and bumbling through a new framework or language. When Will I Be Ready To Begin Applying to Jobs. Yesterday most likely. Don’t make the mistake of waiting until you feel prepared to begin looking for positions or making connections on LinkedIn. I was probably less prepared than you when I began getting paid to code about 7 years ago.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I began getting paid to code about 7 years ago. Apply for anything where you meet around 50% of the requirements. If you meet 100% of the requirements you are almost certainly over-qualified for the job. I Have No Prior Experience, What Should I Put On My Resume. This is a tough one. Treat your resume like code and continue to refactor and iterate on it to improve it and get better results.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on it to improve it and get better results. I have seen people use projects they have worked on with the technologies listed, their role and a link to the repo. Others have put “freelance developer” as their most current position while others just use the same resume they’ve been using before getting into tech. I would only discourage the latter option as it can confuse people.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the latter option as it can confuse people. If you worked at Burger King for the last 4 years, it could be difficult for a hiring manager to feel comfortable taking a chance on you or worse, assume you are not applying for a software developer position and toss your resume to their dog or toddler or whatever. I Want To Do X But I’m Waiting For YOk, this isn’t really a question but I hear some variation of this from too many people.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: hear some variation of this from too many people. “I want to start writing about this framework but I’m not an expert. ” “I want to apply for this job but I’m not quite ready. ” “I want to start doing LeetCode but first I need to brush up on my CS fundamentals. ”I’ve said all of these things myself and finally realized how much time I wasted waiting for the right time. Write that article, apply for that job and stop letting LeetCode intimidate you.

metadata.title: Questions I Get Asked From Junior Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: That’s surprising but I’ve had a similar experience before and it’s easy to forget that a lot of teams just forgo testing and crank out pretty decent software… amazing even.

metadata.title: That’s surprising but I’ve had a similar experience before and it’s easy to forget that a lot of…
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A ProposalNo pressure — we’re all just gonna stand around staring intensely as you code for our amusement. No pressure though. A member of your team has just left for another opportunity 😢. While you and your team are excited for them, you also realize you have a backlog of user stories with looming deadlines. It’s time to hire. You believe you need a warm body capable of producing code to maintain your team’s average output. You’re not totally wrong.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: team’s average output. You’re not totally wrong. I would argue that in order to continually improve your team, maintain engagement and create great products — what you really need is a person who can increase its average technical ability. A bar-raiser. This bar-raising developer will ideally offer more or deeper technical expertise and/or skills that will be needed in the near future.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: skills that will be needed in the near future. Your current team gets the benefit of this person’s knowledge and offers this new member an opportunity to mentor others in a meaningful way and learn from them as well. Now, how do you determine what constitutes a bar-raising candidate. A LeetCode style interview just won’t cut it here.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: A LeetCode style interview just won’t cut it here. You may get the best damn competitive programmer in your local area only to realize they aren’t actually that good at what your team really does — create UI focused web apps. Or social media networks that tear at the very fabric of society. Or whatever. A game of engineering trivia may net you a candidate who has read through all the docs surrounding popular programming languages. Can you explain how a left-join works. How about the IE box-model.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: how a left-join works. How about the IE box-model. Blah. Here is my controversial proposal:Identify the true skills your team currently needs and what it will need in the future. For a front end focused team, perhaps page load time and writing performant React components is a weak spot. You also know that an effort to migrate some JS apps to Typescript is on your technical roadmap. Here’s the weird part. Test a representative slice of your own team on the skills you have identified in part 1.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: team on the skills you have identified in part 1. Have them take the same test/challenge you plan to use for candidates. Score your current team on their performance in the challenge you’ve given using a discrete set of criteria. What is the average score. Using this same test/challenge you now have a baseline that candidates need to “beat” in order to be considered bar raisers. Candidates who do considerably better than your team are likely worth moving forward in the process.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are likely worth moving forward in the process. Those that do about the same may be good enough if they’ve shown promise in other areas and those who score significantly lower will be the least likely to move forward. As an added benefit, your team now has an intimate knowledge of the process you are using to hire.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: knowledge of the process you are using to hire. Outlandish expectations and time sucking challenges will hopefully be extinguished before reaching the public and you now have an arguably more objective method to understand how new candidates compare with your current team members and their relative level of seniority.

metadata.title: The Software Engineer Interview Solution — A Proposal
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End DeveloperPlot twist, a LeetCode question was behind each doorInterviews are weird. You likely do them in spurts every few years and if you’re not practicing in between these high stakes periods, you don’t really know what to expect. They can be stressful, completely orthogonal to the type of work you do on a daily basis and leave you doubting yourself.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on a daily basis and leave you doubting yourself. Many people would rather stay in a less than desirable company for lower pay than subject themselves to the interview circuit. More often than not, the fear of interviewing stems from a lack of knowledge and preparedness. If you know what to study and what to expect, it can make the interview feel a lot less like a terrible game of mystery bag.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a lot less like a terrible game of mystery bag. After going through too many interviews to count, here are the 3 most common formats I’ve encountered:The Game of TriviaWho: Non-tech companies, large companies, older companiesWhat: The interviewer will go through a list of questions related to the primary programming language they use at work. The more obscure the questions, the more you should question whether you want to work here or not.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: question whether you want to work here or not. For front-end focused roles, you should expect to answer questions about the event-loop, closure, ES6 and this. How to Study: Read MDN docs around Javascript and be prepared to answer the most common JS questions like the difference between let and const or bind, call, apply. Refresh yourself on browser APIs and scope and don’t forget closure.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: browser APIs and scope and don’t forget closure. The LeetCode-Style InterviewWho: Tech companies, FAANG and FAANG-adjacent companies, startups who think they WILL be FAANG adjacent 😉What: This is by far the interview that most developers will prepare for, although I’d argue the majority of companies will not ask you these types of questions 🤷‍♀. Do I even really need to explain what happens here. A question ripped directly from LeetCode or a very similar one is given to you with a time limit.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: similar one is given to you with a time limit. You ask the interviewer/s some questions and dive into writing code. How to Study: These questions typically center around data structures and common algorithms. Study graph/tree traversal, string manipulation, sorting/searching algorithms, and recursion. You’re less likely to see questions that involve linked-lists in my experience.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that involve linked-lists in my experience. Build a UI Component/Extend FunctionalityWho: FAANG, startups, and non-tech companiesWhat: This is the interview you are most likely to encounter and there seems to be an industry trend towards these interviews as of late (likely because companies are starting to see diminishing returns on the LeetCode style interview).

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: returns on the LeetCode style interview). I’ve done this interview about a dozen times: build a React component that fetches some data asynchronously and displays it in a visually pleasing way. A variation of this interview is to give a candidate a component that has some bugs that need fixing. More often, I’m seeing unit testing as part of these interviews. How to Study: I’ve had the best luck on these interviews by doing side projects using ReactJS.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: interviews by doing side projects using ReactJS. If you work as a front-end developer, you hopefully get enough practice in your day to day work but I would suggest familiarizing yourself with CSS animations, event listeners and window. fetch since an interviewer may not allow you to use a 3rd party library for HTTP requests 😅. Not so Honorable MentionsThese interviews are common enough but just don’t appear with the same frequency as the ones I’ve mentioned above.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: same frequency as the ones I’ve mentioned above. The Take Home ProjectWho: Small companies, startups, junior positionsWhat: Build us something for free. The company gives you a prompt to build a small app. You waste your weekend for free and then go onsite to do 1 of the 3 aforementioned interviews. How to Study: Don’t. Just don’t.

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: interviews. How to Study: Don’t. Just don’t. System-ish DesignWho: Small companies, startups, FAANGWhat: System design for front-end developers can often involve state management tactics for composing large applications or can be a more traditional system design exercise like building a rate-limiter. I’ve been asked to solve an actual issue the team has faced in the past as well (my personal fave).

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: has faced in the past as well (my personal fave). How To Study: Honestly, as a front-end developer, you will have a bit more room for error here in my opinion(excluding FAANG companies who will have a higher bar and less tolerance for shallow answers). To be safe, study the most common system design questions like designing a rate limiter, building Uber, building a tiny-URL shortener, and be ready to talk about the tradeoffs with state management tools (ex: Redux vs React’s Context API).

metadata.title: The 3 Types of Interviews You Will Encounter as a Front End Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React ComponentsHave you ever written a fairly simple React component only to get bogged down in complicated tests. 🙋It may start like this — you create a simple shopping cart component for an e-commerce site. Someone from marketing only wants logged in users to see a certain visual display. Ok no prob. The backend team makes a change to the API for ordering items — now logged in customers must call a different endpoint.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in customers must call a different endpoint. No big deal, you simply add in a condition to determine which url to use. Inevitably, this will not be the last request for changes to your “simple” component. But you leave that for your future self to figure out 😉. Your component works. Now it’s just a matter of writing tests to maintain your team’s test coverage threshold.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to maintain your team’s test coverage threshold. You realize you now need to mock the redux store in order for the test component to grab the logged in state as well as the http request library you are using 😅. You shake your fist in anger at your past self. How could you you, you whisper, looking in the mirror.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: could you you, you whisper, looking in the mirror. Your current component looks something like this:Using the principle of Inversion of Control we can create some abstractions on top of our http client axios and use a container to implement the addToCartFunction for our ShoppingCart. Inversion of Control is a principle for composing software which basically offloads the implementation of custom logic outside the class or in this case the component where it is being used.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in this case the component where it is being used. In IoC, custom-written portions of a computer program receive the flow of control from a generic framework. — WikipediaIn the example above we have made some significant refactoring to our original ShoppingCart component. We have now implemented a ShoppingCartContainer to act as a dependency injection container and will take care of the actual implementation of our addToCartFunction.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: actual implementation of our addToCartFunction. We have also abstracted away the direct call to a 3rd party library axios and replaced it with a generic apiClient class to handle http requests. A unit test can now handle the implementation of apiClient and it becomes trivial to mock or stub it and ensure it is called with the correct arguments using library like jest. ShoppingCart no longer implements addToCartFunction and can be used in a different context with a different function.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in a different context with a different function. Now when a new use case is introduced for the cart — we can simply pass in a different function rather than appending more logic and increasing cyclomatic complexity.

metadata.title: Using Inversion of Control to Write More Easily Testable React Components
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement RateAre you really surprised by this. Most recently, Lambda School was publicly shamed for making up employment statistics about their graduates. Lambda School placed only 30% of its 2020 graduates in qualifying jobs during the first half of 2020. This figure is in stark contrast to the 74% placement rate it advertised for its 2019 graduatehttps://www. classcentral.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for its 2019 graduatehttps://www. classcentral. com/report/lambda-school-placement-rate/Now, I’ve worked at a few bootcamps over the years, but you don’t need to have worked at one of these schools to understand the challenges that await recent graduates in the job market. Been on LinkedIn lately. How many articles will you read today from recent grads that haven’t been able to find a job in 3 months. 6 Months. 1 year. Or who have completely given up and gone back to their former career.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: given up and gone back to their former career. It can be demoralizing to read through these stories as a developer on the job hunt. I don’t want this to be all doom and gloom, however. Yes, your bootcamp is likely using creative math to inflate their job placement numbers or outright lying like Lambda School.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: numbers or outright lying like Lambda School. We are humans at the end of the day and there are too many external factors that can affect your personal job search to ever guarantee that you will land a job as a software developer in some finite amount of time. Maybe you barely graduated from your program. Maybe you’re only applying to FAANG (tc or gtfo). Perhaps you just aren’t in a rush to get hired and dragging your feet.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in a rush to get hired and dragging your feet. Maybe it’s just a bad time of year… many companies wait to hire at certain times of the year. There are too many reasons why you, specifically, may not be getting hired. Should you give up on your dreams of becoming a developer and eschew all bootcamp programs. No, you fool. What you should focus on are the foundational skills that will ensure you are prepared when you meet the right opportunity.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are prepared when you meet the right opportunity. The worst mistake I’ve seen students I’ve taught make is to immediately stop coding once their bootcamp ends. Their Githhub history takes a sharp decline the moment guided instruction ends. There are really only 2 problems that recent bootcamp graduates encounter:Not getting interviewsGetting interviews and not passing themLuckily, these are solvable problems. Each requires a different skillset but they are far from insurmountable.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: skillset but they are far from insurmountable. Don’t get bogged down in the sob stories littering LinkedIn or the fact that your bootcamp program may not be forthcoming in their actual job placement numbers. Focus on getting 500 connections on LinkedIn. A/B test your resume and keep a side project going to keep your coding skills sharp.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: project going to keep your coding skills sharp. You may not be able to control the length of your search but you can certainly make sure you are discoverable and have the right skills to get hired when the opportunity arises. Want a hand in getting your first (or not so first) job in tech as a developer by learning the skills that will get your discoverable and hire-able. Grab 10 mins on my calendar so I can learn more about where you are and where you want to go.

metadata.title: Yes, Your Bootcamp Is Lying To You About Their Job Placement Rate
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I'm glad to see someone not suggesting using Context API for global state management. It seems to be gaining popularity as an alternative to redux which doesn't seem like its intended purpose. Context is for sharing state and tightly couples state management with the React API. Good advice here and some mistakes I've been guilty of 😬.

metadata.title: I'm glad to see someone not suggesting using Context API for global state management.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform MigrationsYou may not be familiar with the strangler pattern even if used it in the past. Working on a software team, you’ve likely been faced with a massive refactor or migration to a new platform/codebase/service architecture. Let’s say for example that your company wants to port all their widgets currently written in Jquery to ReactJS. These widgets are exported via a library and imported into a web app.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: via a library and imported into a web app. You have some choices in how to approach this. All or Nothing. Your team begins re-writing widgets to use ReactJS. There are dozens. Some more complicated than others. You estimate it will take 6 months to fully migrate your legacy code to the new framework. About 9 months later (because no one can estimate a project this large) your team is finally ready to flip the switch. Uh oh. A PagerDuty alert pops up on your phone. Followed by another.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: alert pops up on your phone. Followed by another. And another. 😳The decision to switch all of your widgets over at once has backfired spectacularly. Previous functionality is not working as expected. Certain features are missing patches that were merged to the legacy code base. It’s a mess. You cry over your half-eaten burrito in shame. You fool. There was a better way.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in shame. You fool. There was a better way. The Strangler PatternStrangler Pattern is a way of migrating a legacy system incrementally by replacing existing functionalities with new applications and services in a phased approachMost articles about the strangler pattern consider at migrating backend services but the same principle can easily be applied to front-end related migrations like the one mentioned above.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: related migrations like the one mentioned above. Rather than porting over all widgets at once, a safer strategy would be to have 2 separate libraries for the widgets: one for the legacy widgets and another for the ReactJS components. Once a widget was ported to use React, it would replace its legacy sibling. The legacy and new widgets would live in tandem, with the new widgets slowly becoming the dominant species in the code ecosystem.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the dominant species in the code ecosystem. An additional safety net might include using feature flags to toggle between the old and new widgets. Feature flags are decision points in code that determine whether or not invoke certain logic/UI display and are often controlled via a 3rd party app like split. io. If an unexpected feature cropped up in the new widget 😉, a simple flip of the feature flag would display the old, reliable widget.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: flag would display the old, reliable widget. Its Not Always About Writing CodeAs software engineers, a large portion of our job involves writing code, but sometimes what we really need are patterns for common issues that are code-related but don’t necessarily involve writing code. Migrations are such a common issue that software teams encounter that it’s worth exploring different strategies to perform them and saving potentially months of headache by having a clear path forward.

metadata.title: Strangling Your Legacy Codebase: A Safe Way To Perform Migrations
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Thanks Kelly. And absolutely - one of my first projects was a massive migration like that and it failed in spectacular fashion. All the finger and toe crossing I could muster didn't save me 😬.

metadata.title: Thanks Kelly!
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Getting Sober: The First 30 DaysNo fucking thanksAbout 7 years ago I woke up under a bridge. Well, that’s not quite true. To wake up you have to have first been asleep. It’s more accurate to say I was smoking meth under a bridge. Like a troll. A meth troll. I wasn’t homeless by the way. Believe it or not, I was actually working at the time. A professional job with a buttoned shirt and everything. Crazy right. But not as crazy as you may think. My story may be like yours.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: as you may think. My story may be like yours. Maybe instead of blowing out meth clouds under a bridge with your homeless dealer, you’re drinking one or three or 5 too many drinks on a Wednesday. Maybe you like to drink a few nose beers on a Friday 😉. If you’ve ever wondered to yourself, “Do I have a problem. ” Yes my friend, you do. You have a problem. You know it. How do you know if you have a problem, you ask. Well, it’s simple. If you’ve ever wondered to yourself, “Do I have a problem.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ever wondered to yourself, “Do I have a problem. ” Yes my friend, you do. How’d I Do It. Fast forward 7 years and my life is unrecognizable. No more bridges. No meth, coke or alcohol. I’m a software engineer and an avid fitness enthusiast. I even made it to my trainer’s Instagram page as a before/after example 😎. So how’d I go from meth smoking, coke snorting, 40 guzzling degenerate to software engineer gym bro in a little over a year and stay there. No, I didn’t go to AA.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: over a year and stay there. No, I didn’t go to AA. Court ordered treatment. Nah. Jail stint. Nope. I did have an intervention though. Yup, just like you see on TV. It was Easter Sunday and my mother dropped my house. My girlfriend and our 2 kids were sick of my shit. They were going to leave if I didn’t pull it together. Hell, I was going to die at the rate I was going. My mom read me a letter, gave me an ultimatum and she cried. I cried. I was pissed.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: an ultimatum and she cried. I cried. I was pissed. Also, I was drunk and hadn’t slept because, you know…. cocaine. Fuck it. I’ll try, I said. I really just needed her to stop crying. I’d give this thing a few days and wait for it to blow over. How I Stumbled Into CommitmentI had no idea how I was going to get through the first week. But I had to do that much at least. Since 18, I had never gone more than 3 days without drinking. I told my friends I wasn’t drinking anymore.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I told my friends I wasn’t drinking anymore. I told everyone I knew about what had happened and that I’d be out of the drinking game for a bit. So… how long you gonna stop. Something about the way people asked me that question got to me. Or maybe, my own insecurity about my ability to really quit got to me. So I responded, “I don’t know. ”Telling everyone that I was done with drinking for the time being put me in a tight spot. I couldn’t backslide too quickly now.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tight spot. I couldn’t backslide too quickly now. How embarrassing would it be if someone saw me in the bar just a week after I told them I’d been intervention-ed. I threw away all the alcohol in the house. I erased the dealers’ numbers out of my phone. Now what. What Do I Do With All This Time. The 24 hours in a sober day creep by a lot slower. My sleep was fucked. I was either barely able to pass out or taking 12 hour marathon snooze sessions. I wanted sweets. Lots of them.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: snooze sessions. I wanted sweets. Lots of them. At night I’d walk to the local liquor store and pick up a pack of gummy bears, a chocolate bar and a soda. Anything to fill the spot. Weekends were the worst. I needed something to fill in the time I spent at bars or milling around the city in a drunken stupor. Movies take up large chunks of time. So I rented and went out to every movie that looked watchable. It’s still one of my favorite sober habits.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: It’s still one of my favorite sober habits. Eventually, I began looking into other hobbies, like computer programming which ended up leading me into a new career. Exercising quickly followed. I started out running for a little under a mile. Years of smoking had left me in hideous shape and the candy bar habit I picked up wasn’t really helping either. I didn’t exactly know why I was running but I kept at it. I liked the feeling at the end of a run and letting my mind wander during it.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: end of a run and letting my mind wander during it. Maybe I can do this, I thought. So far, so good. Happily Ever After. I still get cravings. I still have a massive urge to backslide that seems to come out of nowhere. So I write about it. I share my story and exercise like a mad man. I watch movies on Thursday nights and go to the theatre a lot. I still eat a fucking ton of candy 😅. What You Need to Do Right NowTell everyone you are going to quit — this makes your success more likely.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to quit — this makes your success more likely. It will also tell you a lot about what your “friends” think of you. Throw away everything in the cabinet. Why sabotage yourself you damn fool. Don’t test your willpower. You’ve already proven you have little of it. Fill in the time. Eat terrible shit. Do a 1000 piece puzzle. Watch a fuckton of movies. Better yet, exercise and read. Whatever. Do something. Anything. Well, do anything but also… exercise. Yeah, you have to.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: do anything but also… exercise. Yeah, you have to. It’s the easiest way to ensure your long term sobriety. I don’t give a fuck what article you read or who told you different. You MUST exercise. Lastly, stop worrying about the future. It sounds corny but just get through each day. Own the day and you will be on a path to long term sobriety. Not drinking for a year sounds impossible. Start with a day.

metadata.title: Getting Sober: The First 30 Days
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Thank you so much. Definitely a lot to learn in leading others still. It's a weird story to share but hopefully it helps someone out there.

metadata.title: Thank you so much!
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Oh totally agree… it’s like trying to lose weight and keeping a tray of chocolate cookies in the fridge. Candy and exercise has been a theme I see over and over with people who quit. We miss all that sugar in our drinks maybe 🤷‍♂.

content: Thanks so much. Gotta bake up the next one.

metadata.title: Thanks so much! Gotta bake up the next one

content: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]Or How Not to Annoy Your Pair Programming PartnerEvery time you copy and paste using the toolbar I die a little bit insideEver pair with a developer who has no knowledge of the code editor they are using. No. Well, my friend you may be that developer. I certainly was. I had been using Visual Studio Code (no, not VSCode 😉) for a couple years and had recently switched to a startup where most of the devs were using VSCode.

metadata.title: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: startup where most of the devs were using VSCode. I was pairing with a super-senior engineer on the team on my first day. Things were going… not well. He was visibly frustrated and after about an hour of pairing he cut our session short. “Hey, I’m going to send you a set of commands I use for VS Code and I want you to get familiar with them” he said, matter of factly. “Uhhh. Ok. ”Years later, I now feel his pain.

metadata.title: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “Uhhh. Ok. ”Years later, I now feel his pain. So much of writing code for larger applications is being efficient in finding code, moving blocks of text around and leveraging the tools to do repetitive tasks. Struggling to find files or wasting time with the intricacies of your editor wastes time and makes the experience of pairing feel tedious or at worst, painful. Behold.

metadata.title: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: pairing feel tedious or at worst, painful. Behold. The shortcuts you NEED to be using in VSCodeThe Basics (… you’d be surprised)Copy: Cmd + cPaste: Cmd + vSave: Cmd + sFinding StuffSearch for text within all files: Cmd + Shift + fSearch for a folder/file using regex : Cmd + pGo to a specific line number within a file: Ctrl + gManipulating TextMove a line of text/block of text up or down: Opt + arrow up || arrow downSelect multiple instances of the same text: Cmd + d (do this multiple times to continue selecting more instances)Comparing FilesSplit screen vertically: Cmd + \Split screen horizontally: Cmd + Shift + \Miscellaneous StuffClose a window: Cmd + wNew window: Cmd + nOpen integrated terminal: Option + `Open keyboard shortcuts: Cmd + k + sYour TurnSee that last shortcut above 🔼.

metadata.title: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: + k + sYour TurnSee that last shortcut above 🔼. You can change the key bindings by opening the keyboard short cuts and use your own special incantation to create the key combinations that make sense for you. For example I toggle my file explorer by using Cmd + 1 🤷‍♂These shortcuts may seem trivial but they will increase your productivity or at least make you much more enjoyable to pair with 😅.

metadata.title: How to Use VS Code Like A Pro [For Mac Users]
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: make you much more enjoyable to pair with 😅. Subscribe to my weekly newsletter for actionable advice and tips to accelerate your career as a JS developer. One short piece delivered each Saturday Morning.

metadata.author: Brian Jenney
