content: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software DeveloperCould there be a worse time to learn to code. I was nearly 30, had been sober for less than 2 months and had a 1 year old and and 8 year old at home. I worked an office job which I just started and drove for Lyft and Uber on the side. There was no time. So I made time. In the process of learning how code, I learned the 2nd most important skill as a software developer (right after coding): the art of time management.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: (right after coding): the art of time management. Unfortunately, I’ve seen too many developers make these mistakes:Freestyling their dayBeing intense but not consistentNot working in their optimal hoursAs software developers we are judged nearly as much on the quality of our code as the time it takes to get it delivered. If your beautiful, bug-free code is consistently shipped weeks after the due date, you will likely not have a job.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the due date, you will likely not have a job. Here’s how I’ve been able to find time to code, run my side business and do over 700 calls with developers around the world while having a family, working full time and maintaining a daily exercise routine. Fail to plan, plan to fail. Ever sit at your computer and think, “Hmmm, what will I do today. ”“I bought that one Udemy course, but then there’s LeetCode and my side project I need to finish” 🤔Analysis paralysis sets in.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I need to finish” 🤔Analysis paralysis sets in. You open 23 tabs and go between multiple tasks that never actually get done. There’s a better way. The night before or in the morning, write down the most important task you should be completing for the day. Spend the very first part of your day tackling that 1 thing before the day gets in the way. For me, that means as soon as I get up, I go to my computer and work on the most difficult thing for my day. No meditation. No cold plunge.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: thing for my day. No meditation. No cold plunge. Just targeted work. Less is more… but you need to do less more… 🤔I’ve taught more people how to code at this point than I can count. I also run a successful and very small mentorship program for people who want to switch careers into tech. Apply here. Here’s how I know if they’re gonna fail or succeed:Me: “So were you able to get through that assignment.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “So were you able to get through that assignment. ”Them: “Nah, not really but this Saturday I have the day off so I’m gonna study for 12 hours”Me: 😬I can’t think of 1 time this has worked out for a student I’ve mentored. The problem with zero studying during the week and marathon sessions on your day off is that you enter into hamster-wheel style learning mode. You wonder why you can’t retain information despite cramming and it’s because you aren’t building up that muscle memory.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: because you aren’t building up that muscle memory. If you wanted to get in shape would you only run 5 miles on Saturday and eat like a fool the other 6 days. Personally, I spent about 30–60 mins learning to code every day and more time on the weekends when I had time. The key to my progress was consistency. I NEVER spent an entire day learning at that beginning stage. Everyone is a morning personDevelopers are naturally late creatures.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: personDevelopers are naturally late creatures. I’ve never been at a company where developer meetings start at the beginning of the day. That being said, the best developers I’ve met tend to make optimal use of the morning. For the majority of us, this is the time of the day where we are least likely to be interrupted. I’m writing this article in the morning while my kids sleep and before they wake up and yell at me to make pancakes or whatever.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: up and yell at me to make pancakes or whatever. Maybe you truly are not a morning person or have some unique schedule which prevents you from working in the early part of the day. That’s OK. Everyone has a time of the day where they find themselves in the “zone”. I’ll be frank — for 99% of us, that is the morning despite what you’ve been told or the fact you just don’t like waking up.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: told or the fact you just don’t like waking up. BUT — if you must, then find another time of day that you can optimize for those difficult tasks like side projects or learning a new language and make it consistent. But… I still have no timeSomething might have to give. Open up your phone. Look at your screen time stats. How many hours are you spending on YouTube, IG (follow me 😉) or Netflix. You may have a little more time than you think.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: You may have a little more time than you think. Make your creative time non-negotiable and schedule it on your calendar. Write down your plans the night before on a scrap of paper next to where you work or sleep. Have your laptop open on the kitchen table with the thing you’re supposed to work on. Skip the cold plunge before opening your laptop. Little tweaks can have a large impact. At Parsity, we don’t simply teach you how to program.

metadata.title: The 2nd Most Important Skill You Need as a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Parsity, we don’t simply teach you how to program. We specialize in working with busy adults who want to switch careers into tech. Apply here.

metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software EngineerYou may feel a range of emotions here. I want to share some controversial opinions about coding that should absolutely not be controversial. Let me be clear — these are my opinions AND they’re rooted in experience with a dash of data to back them up. Before learning to code, switching careers and becoming a moderately influential influencer on LinkedIn (so lame, I get it) — I was speed running life.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: (so lame, I get it) — I was speed running life. Drugs, crime, high speed chases, the whole nine. I reveal a bit about my shady past here in case you’re interested: a story about my past lifeWe’re not here to talk about my poor life decisions though. We got bigger fish to fry. The internet is littered with beginner experts with loud voices and the ability to infect millions with brain rot. Critical thinking is at an all time low. Loud idiots are having a glorious moment.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: low. Loud idiots are having a glorious moment. Let me be ultra-transparent: I own a business that coaches career changers into tech (don’t you dare call it a bootcamp). I’m also an aging software engineer and a father. What we are telling the younger generation is strangling our talent pipeline and flat out wrong in many cases. Here’s what I really think about learning to code, AI, tech influencers and JavaScript. Degrees and coding bootcamps are scams. And they also work.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: coding bootcamps are scams. And they also work. I was an engineering manager for a few years at a large (non-tech) company. I hired nearly a dozen people and interviewed many more. I read too many resumes to count. As a manger, when I came across a resume from a Stanford grad or someone from some smarty-pants college, I would read it a little more closely. That’s it. They got the same interview as the dude who graduated high school.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: interview as the dude who graduated high school. However, the majority of our hires were CS grads even though we had zero education requirements. This should not shock you. If you spent 4 years learning about software, design patterns and coding then you’re likely to be a good candidate for a career in software. If you went to a bootcamp and didn’t get hired in 3 months for a fraction of the price — people somehow consider that a scam. Interesting.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: people somehow consider that a scam. Interesting. How you acquire your coding knowledge is of ZERO importance. Self-teach, go to a bootcamp or go to a university. None of them has a monopoly on knowledge or a magical formula that will guarantee you a job. College-aged people are much more likely to complete a rigorous academic program than a father of 2 who’s juggling work, a failing marriage and aging parents. Is it any wonder most bootcamp students fail.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Is it any wonder most bootcamp students fail. Requirements for degrees in the US, especially in tech, are usually at companies you wouldn’t want to work for anyway. I’ve noticed an interesting phenomenon: the more a company cares about a degree — the less likely they are to be high-paying, flexible or use a modern tech stack. But, hey, do you boo. Takeaway here. No. One. Cares. Learn to code however the hell you want. Bootcamps have high distrust because they accept anyone.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: have high distrust because they accept anyone. A college has a big barrier to entry. Maybe don’t tell people you went to a bootcamp if you decide to go that route. Learn through YouTube, books, college or a coding bootcamp. Build something complex. Be above average. Be curious. AI made coding obsolete. Which increased tech jobs. Next time some nerd on a podcast tells you that AI is taking developer jobs, ask yourself “Why would they say that. ”Clicks. Clout.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: yourself “Why would they say that. ”Clicks. Clout. Maybe it’s because developers tend to be high paid and annoying to work with. There’s nothing more any CEO would love to do than automate us away. Big tech knows how gullible normies are: Metaverse anyone. Have you used Bitcoin to buy a slice of pizza yet. How are your NFTs doing. Is Web3 a thing yet. Tech CEO’s are notoriously upstanding moral people though. So maybe I’m just being paranoid.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: people though. So maybe I’m just being paranoid. Oddly, there are more open tech roles in 2025 than in 2023 (https://www. trueup. io/job-trend). How Sway. Much smarter people than me have written studies that prove innovation leads to more employment opportunities, not less. (https://www. mdpi.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: opportunities, not less. (https://www. mdpi. com/2079-8954/11/8/381)As the barrier to entry for starting an online business becomes nearly non-existent, we have people who don’t know how to code building working apps… that will absolutely not work as they attempt to add more features, security or complex deployment strategies. Imagine asking your uncle to vibe code an app, deploy it on AWS using Serverless and then debug it. How does he decide the database schema. Migrations. Updating libraries.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: database schema. Migrations. Updating libraries. Security patches. Observability. More code === more bugs. More code === more maintenance. More code === more code. Why on earth would you think we need less software developers. FAANG engineers have great advice… for other FAANG engineersFAANG stands for Big Tech Companies You Will Never Get Into. Or something like that. Software engineers at Meta and Google make up around 1% of software engineers in the US.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: make up around 1% of software engineers in the US. Yet they take up most of the online space when it comes to interview tips, day in the life videos and giving general software career advice. 1 problem:You will almost certainly NEVER work for any of those companies. What works at AirBnB will not work at a company where the tech team is 20 people. Your interview will not involve writing algorithms on a Google document.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: involve writing algorithms on a Google document. And yet, here you are, blindly taking the advice of people who went to top Universities at 18, got into the largest tech orgs in the world and think that same advice can apply to you — an adult attempting to switch careers and be happy in a role at a company that no one has ever heard of, making a fraction of what Silicon Valley engineers make, while simultaneously doubling your income. Interesting.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: simultaneously doubling your income. Interesting. My business partner is one of those smarty-pants developers who went to Google. He has excellent advice. He also strongly suggests you don’t consider FAANG for your first job, if ever. The path is too narrow and most devs at Google quit within 3 years anyways. You can still make unreasonable salaries outside big tech and learn skills that are much more transferable. If big tech is your personal goal — don’t let me stop you.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is your personal goal — don’t let me stop you. The up side to working at a name brand company is tremendous and I won’t pretend otherwise. JavaScript isn’t a real programming language… it’s the ONLY programming languageNo one, and I mean no one, uses JavaScript for serious software. Except:NASANetflixUberLinkedInWalmartPayPalJavaScript is the language of the web. That is not changing. You can hate JS. It is everywhere and you will use it at some point.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is everywhere and you will use it at some point. JavaScript has been the 1st or 2nd most popular programming language for years with no real sign of decline. There are only 2 types of programming languages:The ones everyone hates. The ones that nobody uses. Don’t be ashamed to learn JS. Don’t be ashamed to be a JS developer. Also — learn other languages to understand memory management, lower level components and to feel smarter.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: lower level components and to feel smarter. There are too many software engineers and not enoughMore people than ever can code. Poorly. There are tons of amazing coders who don’t care about building good products. If we keep scaring off a generation of talent for clicks, views and clout then who will replace the current generation.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: then who will replace the current generation. If you say AI, I swear to God…But seriously — we need smart people who actually enjoy this profession to join, otherwise how are we supposed to get cushy management jobs with stock options and endless meetings. That’s the dream right. Right. Let’s circle back to that offline. If you hate what I wrote here, good. If you liked it, even better. I always hope it’s helpful in some way.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: better. I always hope it’s helpful in some way. I work with a small amount of people per year who are serious about changing careers and realize it will take longer than 3 months. Me and my business partner are career changers who currently work as software engineers. Let us build you a custom plan that actually gets you hired. Apply here.

metadata.title: Coding Bootcamps are Scams and Other Controversial Takes from a Fed Up Software Engineer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: My Trip to Vibe Coding HellThe road to hell is paved with good intentionsLet me start by saying that I use AI to generate a ton of code. After 10 years of writing code for monies, I have a pretty decent idea of what will and won’t work and opinions on how to construct and deploy web apps. Recently, I joined a new team and we are creating a prototype for a new product. We’re attempting to do this with pure Vibe Coding. Vibe Coding is essentially using AI to craft nearly ALL your code.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: using AI to craft nearly ALL your code. This means that an engineer who might not know JavaScript or TypeScript can build an app via prompts. What could go wrong. It started like this: a product manager showed the (non technical) exec team how use Vercel’s v0 to prompt their way to a beautiful application. They built a prototype in a weekend. It looked incredible. It did nothing. 1000 line-long files — who cares. Optional types everywhere — what could go wrong.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Optional types everywhere — what could go wrong. Massive amounts of videos and large, unoptimized images but hey, it works on my machine. Fake data but don’t worry, we’ll figure that out… laterNone of that mattered. Because it felt like magic. So began our descent into what I now call: Vibe Coding Hell. When “Working Software” is a Shack With a Nice Paint JobThe prototype wowed the execs. They were giddy. “If we can build this in a weekend, imagine what we can build in a month.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a weekend, imagine what we can build in a month. ”So we kept building. We wanted this to work. Cursor-assisted feature after feature. It looked real. It felt real. But underneath. It was a house of cards glued together with fake data and half-baked TypeScript. Every new line of code made it worse. Deploying became a nightmare. All those massive video files couldn’t fit in GitHub. They needed to be hosted somewhere.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: fit in GitHub. They needed to be hosted somewhere. A resource intensive component looked great in v0 but brought our laptops to a crawl becauseThe build failed because of wrong types and slight differences between versions of NextJS. The more code we added, the more unstable the app became. One moment, we were demo-ready. The next, we were breaking everything because Cursor agents went HAM and broke something that had just been working. Yes, we had robust cursor rules.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: been working. Yes, we had robust cursor rules. Yes, the team is all senior developers. Yes, we made it clear to the leadership team that this could NEVER, EVER work in real life. At least not yet. CEOs Want to Believe the MythAnd I get it. AI makes them feel like they’ve cracked the code. Like they don’t need a team of 20 engineers anymore — just some prompts and a dream. We gave them a toy they could run locally. They thought this was the same as deploying.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: They thought this was the same as deploying. They thought they understood development. They started questioning what their actual devs were doing all day. I suspect this is what many early career developers believe as well. You start to wonder if you have any value. If this can do my job, faster — then what the hell will I be doing. Vibe coding can get you to the first 80% of a feature if you’re incredibly lucky and/or your app is simple. The final 20%. That’s where the real engineering happens.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 20%. That’s where the real engineering happens. That’s where tests live. And edge cases. And actual performance. And that’s ONLY on the front end. What about your database schema. Your data pipelines. Security. We’ve only scratched the surface. That’s where you stop building demos and start building software. If you’re a career changer who wants to become an actual software engineer who can think through difficult problems, join me at Parsity.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: through difficult problems, join me at Parsity. ioThe Trap of Fast Prototypes and Slow DeathsEvery startup caught in this vibe coding trap will end up in the same place:Fragile code that can’t scale. Teams that can’t debug what the AI wrote. Founders who thought they were building a Ferrari but got a cardboard cutout instead. Eventually, someone will suggest rewriting it “the right way. ”Guess what. That takes real time. And that’s when reality hits: AI didn’t replace the need for engineers.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: hits: AI didn’t replace the need for engineers. It just made it easier to lie to ourselves and produce trash at scale. Vibe Coding Isn’t the Future. Engineering Still Is. I was a believer. I wanted it to work. I thought, maybe I’m just old. Maybe this IS the future. I want to slap myself. The best engineers in the coming years won’t be the ones who prompt the fastest. They’ll be the ones who know when to say no, who understand systems, refactor and test and debug.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: understand systems, refactor and test and debug. Vibe coding makes great presentation decks. It doesn’t make great products. If you’re leading a team — or building your own thing — don’t fall for the magic show. Fast isn’t free. And real software still requires real work. If you’re a career changer who wants to become an actual software engineer who can think through difficult problems, join me at Parsity. io.

metadata.title: My Trip to Vibe Coding Hell
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught YouYour brain after reading this articleMost people don’t actually know how to learn. They follow tutorials, binge YouTube, copy code, and then wonder why they feel stuck the moment they have to build something original. It’s not a lack of intelligence. It’s a lack of system.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: not a lack of intelligence. It’s a lack of system. In a field like software development, where the tools change monthly and the fundamentals take years to master — having a learning strategy is more important than knowing a tech stack. But most new developers don’t have one. Instead, they default to tools like ChatGPT, Cursor, or hot takes from influencers. Bald ones at that. This is not bad in moderation.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Bald ones at that. This is not bad in moderation. But if you skip the actual process of learning, struggling, debugging and building intuition then you won’t level up. You’ll just look like you’re making progress. I’m not against AI. I use it daily. But if you want to get good, like really good, you need more than shortcuts. You need a system. Here’s the exact one I used to learn how to code at 30 and what we teach at Parsity. io. You can steal it to learn anything.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Parsity. io. You can steal it to learn anything. Step 1: The Protégé effectIf you can’t explain it, you don’t know it. I remember learning JavaScript over a decade ago. I wondered how I could memorize all these abstract concepts. Someone would pay me for this knowledge some day, I figured. I read books and copied the code like a good little boy. Once I put the books away, I had no f*cking clue what to do.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the books away, I had no f*cking clue what to do. A very small tweak gave me a massive results:Write out what you think the code is doing in your own words. I ditched the academic jargon and nerd-speak. Instead, I wrote down how I understood what the code was doing and the output I expected in plain english, dumbed down to the point I was embarrassed that someone might read what I wrote if they looked at my cheap laptop. Turns out, this isn’t just a learning hack. It’s science.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: this isn’t just a learning hack. It’s science. Psychologists call it the Protégé Effect: we learn better when we teach or explain concepts to others. Studies show that even just preparing to teach something forces you to understand it more deeply. Before you teach others, teach yourself by making the abstract obvious. Match foreign concepts to familiar mental models. For example, what do you think of when you think of a JavaScript function. I think of a bomb.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: think of a JavaScript function. I think of a bomb. It’s laying dormant, waiting to be triggered and explode when invoked. Maybe I’m just weird. Find what makes sense to you to create sticky mental models — and maybe never share it out loud. Step 2: You’re a human you idiot. Know Your Limits. I remember mentoring a student at coding bootcamp in the 2010s who would always show up to class early and stay late. He could barely write a for loop. How was this possible.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: barely write a for loop. How was this possible. I asked him how he was studying and he told me, confidently:“I can’t study during the week because I work 2 jobs so I study 10 to 12 hours on Saturday and Sunday. ”My jaw nearly hit the floor. No wonder he wasn’t making any progress. There is a limit to the return on your marathon of studying. Scientists say that limit is, are you ready for this. 90 minutes.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that limit is, are you ready for this. 90 minutes. At Parsity, we encourage mentees to use the Pomodoro technique to practice spaced repetition — basically, taking short breaks in between learning to do something active or rest. Spacing out your learning forces your brain to flex its memory muscles and keep what you learned in its long term memory bank rather than the short term. Remember, your brain is not a computer.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: term. Remember, your brain is not a computer. It wasn’t that long ago that our ancestors were fighting off saber tooth tigers to get home and enjoy a brontosaurus burger. Step 3: A cliche that is truer than you think. Whether you think you can, or you think you can’t, you’re right. It’s cheesy, but also scientifically accurate. Psychologists call this self-efficacy: your belief in your ability to succeed.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: your belief in your ability to succeed. Research shows that higher self-efficacy leads to greater effort, persistence, and ultimately, performance. People who believe they can learn are more likely to keep trying when it gets hard. So no, it’s not just woo-woo mindset talk. Your belief about your ability directly shapes your outcomes. Maybe you think you’re too “dumb. ”You were never good at math. You believe “smart” people are just genetic lottery winners. Perhaps all this is true. Then what.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: winners. Perhaps all this is true. Then what. Do you simply accept that you can never learn anything new or improve your life. Let me be honest: everyone is starting off at a different point and your learning speed will be different than someone else’s. Do your best to compare yourself to yourself instead of others. You can control your habits and consistency when it comes to learning but not the result. So how do you develop this kind of mindset.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: So how do you develop this kind of mindset. Don’t worry, I won’t suggest any cringe influencer routines, just a very practical strategy to develop growth mindset:Leave yourself proof. Record yourself bumbling through explanations to concepts like closure, recursion and inheritance. Write about your struggles in a journal. Keep a “brag document” where you record your victories like finishing your first LeetCode problem, getting your first interview or tackling a particularly hard bug.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: interview or tackling a particularly hard bug. When that voice in your head gets louder and pushier with doubt, telling you that you aren’t cut out for this: read your proof back to that sick bastard. Eventually he (or she) will get quieter. Also — audit that voice in your head. Maybe don’t make it so mean. I may not know you, but I believe in you and I hope you found this helpful.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: believe in you and I hope you found this helpful. Parsity is a program for career changers who are serious about breaking into tech and realize the coding bootcamp model won’t work for them. Apply here.

metadata.title: The 3-Step Learning Framework No One Taught You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got WeirderI’m your totally-not-a-robot interviewerCoding interviews are about to get weirder. I’ve done no less than 10 interviews in the last 12 months. TBH, they’re mostly the same. Live code something with React. Maybe a LeetCode medium. Awkwardly turn off Co-Pilot or Cursor so you don’t complete their challenge in seconds. But recently, something changed. The unexpected AI penalty.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: something changed. The unexpected AI penalty. Many companies explicitly ban you from using AI tools during the interview. If you’re caught, it could ruin your reputation and get you on their do-not-hire list for life. Some companies are opting for in-person interviews to deter cheating. Some companies are going in the exact opposite direction.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are going in the exact opposite direction. Check out this recent job posting for a start-up in LA:If you’re a developer who is avoiding AI tools in order to “hang on to your coding skills” — this may actually hurt you in your next interview. My last interview reflected this new reality. “It’s fine. Keep Cursor on. ”My most recent interview involved a coding challenge to create a full stack NextJS app with an API route that did some string manipulation.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: an API route that did some string manipulation. I shared my screen and opened up my preferred editor, Cursor. Oops. “Oh sorry, I can switch to VS Code and turn off AI tools for this exercise” I said. The CTO paused briefly. “No — it’s fine, keep it on. We want to see how you use AI to approach the challenge. We want you to tackle this the same way you would as if you were working. ”To say I was shocked is an understatement. It makes sense though.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is an understatement. It makes sense though. AI is an integral part of what we do as coders in 2025. I used to be asked how I found answers to problems using Google. Now I was going to expose how I use Cursor to my interviewers. This did not make my interview any easier. It may have been more difficult actually. Why didn’t you use the approach the AI gave you. Blindly copying code from an AI tool is as bad as blindly copying from Stack Overflow. Actually, it’s worse.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: copying from Stack Overflow. Actually, it’s worse. AI can generate slop at a speed we can’t really fathom. If you honestly believe the code generated by AI is THE best approach — you might actually want to go old school until you can use your AI tool the way it works best: as your assistant, not your boss. During the fairly simple challenge, I used AI to scaffold the front end in a single prompt. The backend code it generated however, was un-necessarily complex and bloated.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: however, was un-necessarily complex and bloated. I rejected the response it gave me and opted to code some of it on my own. The CTO asked why. “Any reason you rejected the code it gave you. It looked decent. ”It would work for sure, I explained. However — did we really need to use regex. Would a map work better than an object. Can we decompose this massive function into a few smaller functions for re-use. Overall he agreed with my approach and it led to good discussion. That’s the point.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and it led to good discussion. That’s the point. He’s not hiring an AI agent, he’s hiring a human. For now. If I had copied and pasted the output from Cursor, I’m sure it would work with enough prompting but if you’re not considering maintainability, simplicity and test-ability, then you’re a slave to your tool instead of the other way around. Defending my decisions to use or not use AI-generated code during the interview was much more difficult than I anticipated.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: was much more difficult than I anticipated. Knowing the fundamentals of TypeScript, Javascript and some basic coding principles like the rule of Single Responsibility or Open-Closed principle were useful to explain my thought process and create trust with the interviewers. Know your tools, don’t forget your fundamentals. In 2025, knowing how to use AI tools like Cursor is part of the job. But using them blindly is a fast track to getting exposed in an interview.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a fast track to getting exposed in an interview. I should also mention that out of ~30 interviews this team conducted, I got the offer. I highly doubt I was the best at using Cursor. This low pass rate may say more about the quality of senior engineers out there than anything. Here’s what I’d recommend if you want to stand out in this new era of interviewing:Use your AI tools and be intentional. Don’t just prompt. Edit. Refactor.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: be intentional. Don’t just prompt. Edit. Refactor. Reject suggestions that are bloated or don’t align with best practices. Brush up on your fundamentals because knowing why you’re rejecting AI output matters more than just spotting that it “feels wrong. ”Practice defending your code — explain your choices. Interviewers are listening for reasoning, not just results. Your next interview might come down to you vs. someone who also uses AI and knows when to say no to it. Change is exciting.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: knows when to say no to it. Change is exciting. Change is scary. We fail, we learn and we adapt. As always I hope you found this useful and good luck if you’re preparing for interviews. At Parsity we work with a handful of career changers who want to break into tech with 1 on 1 mentorship from senior+ engineers. Apply here.

metadata.title: The AI Penalty Is Real: Coding Interviews Just Got Weirder
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The AI Developer Career PathWhy TypeScript Engineers Are Perfectly Positioned for the Next Wave of AIThere is a new software engineering role emerging from the dumpster fire that is the tech market. Maybe “new role” is a bit much. It’s more like full stack with an AI twist. Let’s get one thing straight. You will not be building GPT-5. That ship has sailed. OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Meta, and a few others are pouring billions into model training.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: others are pouring billions into model training. And yet some AI bros are out here with a MacBook Air trying to train a trillion-parameter model over free Wi-Fi. There is some investor dumb enough to fund it. Guaranteed. What you are doing — or should be doing — is building around the model. The Python IllusionPython has the AI clout. Fine. Let it. The ecosystem is great for researchers and data scientists.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is great for researchers and data scientists. Meanwhile, most useful LLM applications today look like this:A React frontendAn API that calls OpenAI or AnthropicA database (Postgres, Supabase, Firebase)And increasingly, a vector database behind the scenes (vector databases have become the unofficial choice for AI)If you know how to build a full stack app, you’re 80 percent of the way to building a useful AI-powered app. You just need to understand the new pieces to the AI puzzle.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to understand the new pieces to the AI puzzle. What You Actually Need to KnowHere’s the technologies that will define the LLM engineer career path:Embeddings: Words are turned into vectors. You don’t need to do this by hand, just understand that when you call OpenAI’s embedding endpoint, it returns a list of numbers. These numbers represent meaning. Cosine Similarity and Dot Product: These are the math tricks that help you say “This chunk of text is close to that chunk of text.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: chunk of text is close to that chunk of text. ” That’s how search works in AI. You don’t need to be a mathlete. You need to understand the concept. Vector Databases: These are specialized databases that store text and their vector representations. You query them with vectorized text, and they return the closest matches. Pinecone, Weaviate, and Chroma are the big players here. RAG: Retrieval-Augmented Generation: This is the most popular real-world use case for LLMs.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is the most popular real-world use case for LLMs. RAG means you grab your own data and send it alongside the prompt to the model so it can generate better answers. Over 65 percent of enterprise LLM implementations in 2024 used RAG instead of fine-tuning[source]Fine-tuning is expensive, brittle, and often unnecessary. RAG is boring, popular and incredibly useful. Why TypeScript Devs Are in the Sweet SpotLet’s spell this out.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Devs Are in the Sweet SpotLet’s spell this out. If you’re building anything that:Scrapes contentStores itLets users query itCalls OpenAIStreams back a dynamic responseThen TypeScript probably makes a lot more sense than Python. Users expect highly interactive, live-streaming, beautifully designed interfaces… you know, kinda like ChatGPT. If you’re using ReactJS, Next. js and TypeScript then you’re most of the way there.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and TypeScript then you’re most of the way there. But there’s another reason TypeScript devs have an edge — and it’s not just about UI. LLMs Love StructureOne of the most underrated truths about working with LLMs is that they give better, more consistent responses when your input is structured — and when you can parse the output safely and predictably. This is where TypeScript shines.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and predictably. This is where TypeScript shines. When you’re handling multi-part responses, generating tool invocations, or chaining function calls, having clear types and interfaces actually helps both the AI and your codebase. Clean types. Safe parsing. Real-time feedback. This is the kind of thing modern AI products need and it’s what TypeScript enables out of the box. So How Do You Get Started. Here’s your five-step plan. No fluff. No AI fairy dust. Scrape some data: Use firecrawl.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: No AI fairy dust. Scrape some data: Use firecrawl. dev or build your own simple scraper. Target something public, useful, and structured. Get embeddings: Use OpenAI’s embedding API. It takes in text and returns vectors. Store them in a vector database: Start with Pinecone or Chroma. Chroma is free and runs locally if you’re just experimenting. Build a Next. js app that searches and streams: Send the user’s query to OpenAI with the retrieved context. Show the answer as it streams.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: retrieved context. Show the answer as it streams. Vercel’s AI SDK makes this simple(r). Keep uploading more data and iterate: Build a cron job or trigger to regularly update your dataset. Add support for users to bring their own data. Start thinking like a product person, not a prompt engineer. Final ThoughtsThe hype cycle is almost over. The people building real AI products are already moving. If you’re a TypeScript engineer and you’ve been waiting for permission to get in — this is it.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: waiting for permission to get in — this is it. You don’t need to be a Python expert. You don’t need a PhD. And you don’t need to build your own model. You need to build a product that uses one. And the best way to start is by building something simple, useful, and specific. Your AI career doesn’t start with a paper. It starts with a project.

metadata.title: The AI Developer Career Path
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better CodeBad code is everywhere. Good code is elusive. But, what the hell even is “good” code. Generally, code that is simple to understand, easily extensible and performs well given increasingly larger inputs can be considered “good. ”Simple right. Right. Let me be clear — I’ve written embarrassingly bad code over the last 11 years. I suck a little less every year. Reading books helped. Working with really good developers and reading their code helped.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: good developers and reading their code helped. I’m thankful I learned the “old school” way (aka before AI tools) because I’m seeing just how difficult it is for a new developer to distinguish good from bad when it comes to AI-generated code. Now listen closely: AI tools can write awful code. Really fast. It’s never been more important to identify bad code.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: never been more important to identify bad code. If you want to become a better developer, I’m going to show you how to ask the right questions while writing code or accepting AI-generated code to move yourself closer to writing better code. Unfortunately, most developers assume that AI knows more than they do when it comes to constructing code. You’re too focused on answers. From the start, we’re taught to hunt for solutions. Google it. Ask ChatGPT. Find a Stack Overflow post.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: it. Ask ChatGPT. Find a Stack Overflow post. But when you’re obsessed with answers, you skip the part where you actually understand the problem. Here are a few more reasons developers struggle to ask the right questions:Reason 1: They confuse debugging with problem-solvingFixing an error doesn’t mean you understand the root issue. It just means the red squiggly line is gone. That’s not the same as solving the problem.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: gone. That’s not the same as solving the problem. Reason 2: They don’t write anything downIf you never take the time to write out what you’re building, you won’t see the gaps in your thinking. Writing clarifies confusion. Reason 3: They over-rely on AI and copy-pasteAI tools can help you move faster, but if you skip the step where you understand what’s happening, you’ll build your foundation on shaky ground. Reason 4: You’re afraid to look dumbGuilty as charged.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 4: You’re afraid to look dumbGuilty as charged. I used to fake understanding because I didn’t want to ask a basic question and be judged. The problem is that skipping that question turned into bigger issues later. You can overcome all of this. And when you do, solving problems gets easier. Here’s the questions you should be asking when writing code:Question 1: What am I trying to do. This is the foundation. If you don’t know what success looks like, how can you reach it.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: what success looks like, how can you reach it. Write it out like this:What’s the function or feature supposed to do. What does it take in and return. Where does it fit in the system. Example: “I need a function that takes a user ID and returns their top 3 watched videos from the last week. ”When you write it clearly, you force yourself to define the edges of the problem.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: force yourself to define the edges of the problem. I can’t tell you how many issues have resulted in me, or someone on my team, building a solution to a problem that no one wanted solved. Working remote only increases the likelihood that you maybe walking down the wrong rabbit path. Writing gives clarity. Clarity means speed and confidence. Having clear instructions also means that your little AI assistant won’t go too far off the rails when you ask for help. Question 2: Can I explain this.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you ask for help. Question 2: Can I explain this. Review your own code like someone else wrote itBecause nowadays, “someone” else probably did. Claude. Cursor. Gemini. The usual culprits. Once the code is written, ask: “Is this the clearest, simplest version. ”With AI tools, they seem oddly optimized to give you the most verbose solution to a problem. Sometimes they’ll even make shit up. Claude, you sneaky bastardLook for anything confusing.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you sneaky bastardLook for anything confusing. Pretend you’re a senior engineer reviewing a pull request. Does this make sense without an explanation. Would someone else thank you or curse you six months from now. Remember, we write code for humans just as much as we write it for computers. Your code will be written once and read many times over. Question 3: How many things is this function doing. If the answer is more than one or maybe two things, break it up.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is more than one or maybe two things, break it up. Good code tends to do one thing and do it well. Bad code is the opposite. It tries to do five things and ends up doing none of them cleanly. This is especially important in React components or backend service functions. When you can’t explain what a block of code is doing in a single sentence, that’s your signal to refactor. Having small, tightly focused functions allows you leverage composition.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: focused functions allows you leverage composition. Basically you can mix and match functions or components to achieve different results rather than relying on some massive piece of code that has to be re-written every time your product manager wants to support a different use case. Not like this ever happens in the real world of course 😅. Example:If a component fetches data, handles auth, formats it, and renders UI — that’s four things. Break it up. One function = one responsibility.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Break it up. One function = one responsibility. One component = one concern. This is how you keep your code readable, testable, and maintainable — especially when AI tries to cram everything into a single block. Question 4: Can I delete this. Ask yourself: Does this code need to exist at all. Not like in an existential way. Code is risk. Code is complexity. Code is maintenance. Every line you write is something future-you (or someone else) has to understand and keep alive.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: someone else) has to understand and keep alive. Think of code like rabbits. It multiplies. One quick helper turns into a tangled web of conditionals and edge cases. Your job isn’t just to write code. It’s to remove it wherever you can. Look for:Unused functions or propsOver-engineered helpersConditionals covering imaginary edge casesAI-generated bloat that serves no purposeThe fewer moving parts, the better your codebase will age. If you want to level up, start treating deletion as a skill.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to level up, start treating deletion as a skill. The best devs aren’t just good at building. They’re ruthless editors. You’re only getting startedAn article can only cover so much ground. These questions should push you towards better code and help you separate AI slop from useful suggestions BUT there are so many books written on the topic of writing code that you really should read 1 or 3.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: writing code that you really should read 1 or 3. My favorites, as a full-stack JS developer (don’t roll your eyes) areClean Code in JavaScriptFunctional Light Javascript from Kyle Simpson. I’m not sponsored and those aren’t affiliate links. I have these books in my library and I’m confident they’ll help you. I always hope that’s helpful. In my newsletter I share strategies and exercises for early career developers to accelerate their careers, learn AI in a practical way and generally suck less.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: AI in a practical way and generally suck less. Join here.

metadata.title: These 4 Questions Are the Key to Writing Better Code
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: It's so tempting nowadays too.

metadata.title: It's so tempting nowadays too
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software DevelopersThe software engineering market didn’t die. It just moved on without telling you. We’re in a new era. The bootcamp-to-job pipeline is dried up. Certificates are noise. AI tossed a grenade into the hiring funnel. There are more software jobs open now than there were two years ago AND it’s more difficult to get hired. It feels like the rules are completely different because they are.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: rules are completely different because they are. Here’s some advice that’s too harsh for LinkedIn but I think you’ll find useful if you’re a newer developer on the market. 1. Vibe coding is not a career or a replacement for actual skillCopy/pasting from ChatGPT and “figuring it out later” isn’t a real workflow. Build less like a hacker, more like an engineer. You should understand your tools, the stack, and what happens after you click “deploy.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: stack, and what happens after you click “deploy. ”Vibe coders are running up cloud credits by exposing private information or scrambling to hire back software developers the moment their app grows beyond simple use cases or a few dozen files. I give it another year and “vibe coders” will be regarded with the same reverence as “prompt engineers. ”Remember when that was a thing. 2. No one cares about your certificate. Your Coursera badge. That AI Fundamentals YouTube playlist.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: badge. That AI Fundamentals YouTube playlist. The completion certificate from Parsity. io. (btw — I run this program and still don’t advise mentees to share this… just saying)Hiring managers aren’t impressed and it can actually be a red flag, unless you’re in DevOps or some role that requires AWS/GCP certifications. For any full stack role, these certs are more noise than signal. Certs don’t necessarily hurt but they rarely help. 4. If you must build a portfolio, don’t do it from scratch.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: must build a portfolio, don’t do it from scratch. Use Vercel’s V0 or another AI site builder. This weekend, I vibe-coded an entire site that looks better than anything I could’ve done on my own. Check it out. Should that scare me. I don’t know. I do know that building fancy landing pages is not a job I want to do. AI tools will almost certainly make something better than your hand-coded portfolio that breaks as soon as I put it in mobile view.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that breaks as soon as I put it in mobile view. Let’s be honest: when digging through a stack of resumes, no one is going to look at your links. Following random links is a big no-no at most orgs and managers simply don’t have time. Yes — I’ve met more than a few devs who got hired because of their portfolio. In 2013. 5. Full-stack is the new baseline. “Front-end only” roles are fading. Stack Overflow’s yearly survey reported only 10% of professional developers identify as front-end.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of professional developers identify as front-end. I was shocked and a little sad to see this but it tracks with my experience. Modern teams expect you to be able to touch the backend, databases, and maybe even cloud infra. You don’t need to be an expert in all these areas. You just need to be fluent enough to be deployed to these areas. Start with Node + Express and here’s a free starter kit to get going:👉 https://github. com/CodeCoachJS/node_express_starter6.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: com/CodeCoachJS/node_express_starter6. AI productivity is a lie — but you still have to play the game. There’s a sickening trend of devs claiming they’re “10x more productive” because of AI. Companies want to believe this. Their shareholders are betting on it. What could go wrong. Google found out that AI improved developer productivity by 10%. Not 10x. 10%. But why ruin the fun with facts and numbers. So what do you do.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the fun with facts and numbers. So what do you do. Become “AI-first” — I hate myself a little for even typing that…On the shallow end:Use Cursor or Claude or whateverMention it on your resumeAuto-complete better and fasterExperiment with agents and different models/tools for software developmentManagers are scrambling to hire AI-enabled developers to appease their bosses who told their investors they would become 100x more productive this year by becoming “AI-native” — whatever the fuck that means.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “AI-native” — whatever the fuck that means. Now, if you actually want to develop the hard skills related to LLMs. Learn RAGRead up on transformers, attention mechanisms and paged attentionUse vector databasesBuild agentic workflowsThese are the skills that will actually make you valuable and I cover all of it in the upcoming Parsity AI Developer Course for people who want to build real, modern, AI-powered software. 7. Learning four languages makes you look unfocused. Pick one stack and go deep.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you look unfocused. Pick one stack and go deep. JavaScript + TypeScript is enough. Listing Rust, Go, Python, and Java after six months. 🚩While I’m at it: remove those proficiency levels under the languages you list. No one knows what 65% at TypeScript means and it scares recruiters. 8. You’ll never feel “ready. ”There’s no magical “I’m ready now” moment. Apply before you’re ready. If you meet 50% of the requirements for a role then you need to apply.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: requirements for a role then you need to apply. If you meet 100% of the requirements then you’re over-qualified. Don’t down-level yourself. The titles junior/mid-level/senior mean completely different things at different organizations. Let the interview dictate your ability to do the job. Stop filtering yourself out before anyone else does. 9. Hiring is broken but your network isn’t. Yes, I know some people are still mass applying and getting interviews.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: are still mass applying and getting interviews. But at Parsity, the people who land jobs are doing something else:They’re using their real-world network and it works. They’re former teachers, chefs, EMTs. They find their first job by reaching out to former colleagues, old classmates, friends-of-friends, or local businesses. It’s rarely someone you know directly that can help you with that first role. It’s almost always a friend of friend of a friend. Be methodical and do a BFS of your network.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Be methodical and do a BFS of your network. If you don’t get that reference… look it up. Bottom lineThis market isn’t hopeless. It’s different. It rewards deep skills, real projects, product thinking, and practical AI fluency (or at least the illusion of it 😅). My super opinionated advice:If you’re an early career developer and lacking in technical skills: consider a strategic investment in up-skilling with AI by building out a full stack web app using agents or RAG.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: out a full stack web app using agents or RAG. If you are having zero luck in the job market — consider doing an audit of your network to “shake the tree” and find some people who might be able to point you to someone you can talk to. As usual, I hope that’s helpful and not too harsh.

metadata.title: 8 Harsh Truths for New Software Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Building Your First AI AgentI want you to break what I builtLast year I joined an AI start-up and started building my first agent for a large project we were working on. It was exciting and messy. No one on the engineering team had any expertise with AI or working with LLMs. This “agent” was supposed to take a prompt, determine if we could actually handle the request and then do a search of either a vector database or do a web search.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of either a vector database or do a web search. It might return some text or an array of objects depending on the outcome. It was bloated, inefficient and costly. I had no clue what I was doing. This massive agent was breaking one of the cardinal rules of building software: SRP. Single Responsibility Principle. Our CEO was an AI OG, luckily, and had some experience with agents before they became cool.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: experience with agents before they became cool. He helped us re-think our logic and then we broke up our “agent” in to multiple, self-contained agents that were each responsible for 1 thing. 1 agent to summarize the conversation. 1 orchestrator to decide which agent to call next. 1 agent for a vector search. 1 agent for a web search. Clean. Simple. Cost-effective. Composable.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: search. Clean. Simple. Cost-effective. Composable. While everyone is having an existential crisis about the future of tech — there is a massive re-shuffling happening under our feet. This means massive opportunity. The more I work with AI, the more bullish I am about the future of tech and software engineering specifically.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of tech and software engineering specifically. Most of the same skills that were important before AI will be important going forward: debugging, system design, clean code and solving tough problems with code aren’t going anywhere. Owning a camera doesn’t make you a photographer, much in the same way that writing some code with AI does not make you a software developer. While the “old” skills are still relevant, the tech we use is undergoing a massive overhaul.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the tech we use is undergoing a massive overhaul. Learning how to build agents, work with vector databases and monitor these agents are emerging skills that most developers just haven’t had experience with yet. This shift is why I’m building something for Parsity students to make sure they have exposure to this new tech stack. You can check it out at Parsity. aiBecause I like you, I built a very small project to introduce you to agents using Gemini and plain HTML and JS.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you to agents using Gemini and plain HTML and JS. This project uses 2 agents to estimate how many calories you consumed based on what you ate in the day. One agent determines if we have enough information to provide an estimate of your calories and the other agent returns the estimate. Simple and maybe even useful. You won’t get much out of just reading about it though. The ONLY way to learn is to get your hands dirty.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The ONLY way to learn is to get your hands dirty. Step 1: Get a free key from Google to use their Gemini model: https://aistudio. google. com/apikeyStep 2: Visit https://codepen. io/Brian-Jenney/pen/PwqLQLW. editors=1010 and start getting your hands dirty with the Diet Tracker App. Step 3: Break, re-write and extend the project. Change the output format. Can you add another agent. The only way to actually learn is to get your hands dirty.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: way to actually learn is to get your hands dirty. If the code is out of your depth then you should consider our Dev30 program to help you learn the basics of JS. Enjoy. I write emails to early career developers hereI talk to early career developers here: Develop Yourself.

metadata.title: Building Your First AI Agent
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Tom, pitcured above, is a 35 year old senior software developerIf You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First. When’s the last time you really learned something. Not a quick YouTube tutorial. Not a how-to guide. I’m talking about deep, uncomfortable, make-you-question-how-smart-you-are type of learning. The kind that rewires your brain. For most people, it hasn’t happened since school and that’s part of the problem.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: since school and that’s part of the problem. There’s a reason the traditional path to software engineering involves school. Structured learning, homework and feedback loops train your brain to endure confusion, repetition, boredom, and struggle. But when you’re over 30, trying to switch careers with a job, a family, and limited time… that structure is gone. You’ve probably developed some skills and are pretty good at a few things.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: some skills and are pretty good at a few things. You’re not used to sucking at something new so your tolerance for it is low. 15 Years Ago, My Life Was UnrecognizableI wasn’t sitting behind a laptop writing JavaScript. I was addicted to drugs, drinking heavily, and paying rent through illegal means. Coding wasn’t on my radar. A W-2 wasn’t on my radar. Fast forward seven years: I was flying first class to New York to give a talk in front of a room full of Fortune 500 executives. No CS degree.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: room full of Fortune 500 executives. No CS degree. No Ivy League resume. Just years of self-learning, some luck, and a lot of building. I don’t know many fields that let you completely reinvent your life. Tech does. But don’t confuse that opportunity with ease. This was not easy. And it’s definitely not a get-rich-quick scheme. People join a coding bootcamp, memorize a few things, and expect job offers to rain from the sky in 90 days. When they don’t, they scream “Scam.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: in 90 days. When they don’t, they scream “Scam. ”Let me tell you what the real scam is: thinking you can memorize information and get paid six figures for it. This is not a memorization job. It’s a thinking job. A curious person’s job. And more than anything, it’s a job that rewards the people who learn how to learn. If you’re over 30, thinking of breaking into tech, here are 4 mindset shifts you’re going to need to make to have a shot at success.

metadata.title: If You’re Over 30 and Trying to Learn to Code, Read This First.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: They’re Lying to You About AI ProductivityTech CEOs over-promising and under-delivering. Balderdash. You’re just coping. Am I. <Begin Rant>I’ve been pretty vocal about the over-hype of AI coding tools and I always get the same responses from AI bros:“YoU gOtta PrOmpt bEtteR. ”“This iz a skillz issue dawg”“I’m using [x] and it works perfectly”“I’m a super duper senior architect and I’ve replaced my entire team with AI agents. You’re coping. ”I’d be lying if I said I didn’t doubt myself.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ”I’d be lying if I said I didn’t doubt myself. Maybe they’re right, maybe I’m just not using these tools correctly. But, now I’m convinced. They’re either liars, naive or truly top. 01% coders with whom mortals cannot compete. Every other day I read about some developer who is 10x’ing their output with AI tools. Companies like Salesforce and Microsoft are claiming that AI is making them SOOOOOO productive they just have to fire their developers. So what gives.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: just have to fire their developers. So what gives. Let’s take a look at some big fax and small fax to understand where the truth ends and the hype begins. It’s been 6 months — why are there more developer jobs. Remember when the Lizard King told Joe Rogan that AI would be replacing mid-level engineers in 6 months. That was 6 months ago. Do you remember when Devin was supposed to replace ALL software engineers nearly a year ago. And yet — here we are.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: nearly a year ago. And yet — here we are. Despite all these catastrophic events, there are somehow MORE jobs for software developers in June of 2025 than in June of 2024. (source: https://www. trueup. io/job-trend)It’s almost as if these CEOs are pulling predictions straight out of their… hats. Yeah, that’s what I was going to say. Salesforce boasted that they were cutting around 1,000 jobs this year because of AI.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: cutting around 1,000 jobs this year because of AI. BUT they’re also hiring for “AI-aligned” roles like sales engineers — basically just shifting their headcount. Which leads me to the worst and most pervasive lie about AI:1 Senior Developer === 10 Junior DevelopersI call bullsh*t. Ask any developer who’s working on something moderately complex that includes multiple services or a backend system that is more than 3 months old how much [insert tool here] has helped them with their workflow.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tool here] has helped them with their workflow. It’s like we’re all afraid to admit the truth. Which is… “it depends. ”Truly. Meanwhile, the geniuses on LinkedIn will tell you that they’ve effectively replaced their entire team or at least that they COULD. Ya know, if they wanted. That’s how f*cking effective these tools are. They have an MCP server, a rules file that includes every conceivable scenario their agent may encounter and they write prompts like a cold, dead, robotic Shakespeare.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: prompts like a cold, dead, robotic Shakespeare. Or Tyler Perry. If you’re not seeing the productivity gains, then you’re just using it wrong. Bro. Google did a little study on AI and it’s impact on productivity. 10%. That’s how much more effective their engineers are with AI (source: https://www. businessinsider. com/ai-google-engineers-coding-productive-sundar-pichai-alphabet-2025-6). Outside of tech these gains are more… modest.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Outside of tech these gains are more… modest. One study found office workers unlocked a whopping 3% more productivity (source: https://www. computerworld. com/article/3998244/ai-chatbots-see-fast-adoption-but-deliver-minimal-productivity-gains-study-finds. html). But why ruin the fun with facts and numbers from independent researchers and massive tech companies who meticulously track these kinds of stats. That wouldn’t make for very fun YouTube videos. ROI (Really. Over.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for very fun YouTube videos. ROI (Really. Over. Indexed)Investors aren’t gonna like this one. Companies weren’t happy enough with the magical powers we’ve gained from having AI tools like Cursor, Co-Pilot and ChatGPT. They wanted earth-shattering, society-crippling change. Auto-complete on steroids just doesn’t have the same ring as AGI. So they wrote slide decks promising the world to investors who have been burned by poor planning, high interest rates and bets on web3, blockchain and crypto.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: rates and bets on web3, blockchain and crypto. How are your NFTs btw. Good. Great. IBM did a survey of thousands of execs and found that only a quarter of AI initiatives have achieved their expected return on investment (ROI) so far, and only 16% have successfully scaled AI across the enterprise (source: https://www. techrepublic. com/article/news-ibm-study-ai-roi/). To many people, this would be considered a failure. But when it comes to AI — you just gotta wait.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: But when it comes to AI — you just gotta wait. Another 6 months and we’ll see those bets paying off. For real this time. [reminder to update this article in 6 months and either laugh or cry or both]<End Rant>For every study I’ve referenced here, there is some other study that will probably show the opposite. Those studies are almost exclusively written by people who have a lot to gain from AI hype. In all honesty, I have a lot to gain as well.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: In all honesty, I have a lot to gain as well. I’m a software engineer and a business owner with a business that mentors early-career coders (Parsity. io btw — check out). How much can you really trust anything I say. I have a novel idea. Use the tools for yourself on non-trivial projects with teams of more than 3 people in codebases that aren’t exclusively front end. Draw your own conclusions. Read studies. Look at reality. Do you personally know a single person who has been replaced by AI.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: know a single person who has been replaced by AI. Do you know anyone who’s bought a slice of pizza with crypto. All is not bad though. Personally, this is the most fun I’ve had coding so far in my career. The reality is that I AM more productive. I don’t HAVE to write nearly as much code and I can build a sexy-ass (simple) web app in minutes instead of days. I love the tools. I hate the hype. Anyways — enjoy this blooper reel to end the show. That’s all folks.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: blooper reel to end the show. That’s all folks. See ya’ in 6 months — unless I’m replaced by then.

metadata.title: They’re Lying to You About AI Productivity
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary. Five years ago, during an interview for a senior dev role, I had a panic attack. My heart was pounding. I couldn’t get my words out. I had to ask the interviewer to restart the call. I was embarrassed, shaky, and 100% sure I’d blown it. Plot twist: I got the job, but it was one of many interview disasters I’ve had over the years. And it showed me just how broken my approach was.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: And it showed me just how broken my approach was. Here’s the thing: I was already decent at writing code. I wasn’t struggling to do the job. I was struggling to get the job. That’s a really frustrating place to be. In one interview at the beginning of my career, a guy asked me about JavaScript object referential equality. I fumbled hard. He ended up explaining it to me during the call, like I was a student — not a candidate.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the call, like I was a student — not a candidate. Another time I bombed a Facebook interview so badly that I just cut it short. I couldn’t solve a recursion problem and I knew I was just wasting time so I pulled the plug and bailed early. I left these interviews thinking:Maybe I’m just not cut out for this. But I’m stubborn. And obsessed with patterns. So I started breaking the whole process down and rebuilding it from the ground up. Here’s what changed everything:1.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the ground up. Here’s what changed everything:1. I Built a Library of Personal StoriesI’ve done somewhere around 100 interviews in the last 11 years as an engineering manager and software engineer. I’ve noticed that most interviews have the same 4–5 behavioral questions, just reworded:Tell me about a time you solved a hard technical problemTell me about a time you had a conflict with a teammateWhat’s a project you’re proud of. When did you fail.
