metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a project you’re proud of. When did you fail. So I started cataloging real stories from my work that mapped to those questions. I’d jot them down in a doc, grouped by theme. I knew the stories cold — what happened, what I learned, and what they revealed about me. As an engineering manager, I asked these same questions and what I realized I was really trying to understand was:“Can I imagine this person working here. ”Once I understood that, I shaped my own stories to “sell” myself.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that, I shaped my own stories to “sell” myself. What good is passing the coding round in an interview just to bomb the behavioral sections. These questions will often make up the majority of your interview rounds and yet they get the least attention online. Here’s an exercise for you to help organize a technical story for your next interview: Link to the document2. I Got Clear on the Technical GapsI didn’t try to become a master of everything.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: GapsI didn’t try to become a master of everything. I focused on the concepts that tripped me up repeatedly: closures, prototype inheritance, recursion and coding challenges. I built small projects in vanilla JavaScript. I made videos explaining these concepts out loud. I wrote code until I didn’t need to look things up anymore. Eventually, I compiled all of it into a repo I now share with the devs I mentor and it often kicks their ass. 3. I Trained Myself to Be CalmThis was the hardest part.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Myself to Be CalmThis was the hardest part. I’m naturally a nervous, high-energy person. So I did something weird: I sought out interviews I knew I’d fail. Just to get used to the feeling. I used Pramp. I interviewed with strangers. I bombed questions. I embarrassed myself. But I got used to it. This was not fun. This was super effective. After a while, interviews started to feel routine. Like skydiving (at least, I imaging): terrifying the first time, boring after 100 jumps.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: terrifying the first time, boring after 100 jumps. I wanted interviews to be boring. And eventually… they were. The Result. My salary went from $60K to a peak of $290K, with a $200K base. Obviously, the salary bumps changed my life, but more importantly, I’m a lot less worried about IF I can land another role. Learning to interview is the single most high leverage skill you can have as a software developer. Is it fair. NoIs it reality. F*ck yes it is.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Is it fair. NoIs it reality. F*ck yes it is. And now, I help other developers do the same, in addition to running Parsity. io — an anti-coding-bootcamp for career changers. Want to finally get interviews into a chokehold. If you’re a developer with 1–5 years of experience, and you’re tired of being stuck at the same salary or bombing interviews you know you should’ve crushed — I have something for you. I do NOT do FAANG prep. Go to NeetCode, Interview.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I do NOT do FAANG prep. Go to NeetCode, Interview. io, AlgoExpert or Interview KickStart for that. All great programs and I can personally vouch for AlgoExpert and Interview KickStart. Not sponsored in any sort of way — but I probably should be. I only take 5 people at a max at any given time. If you’re in the US, there’s a damn good chance this unlocks $10K–$50K+ in your next move. 👉 Fill out this short form to apply.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: next move. 👉 Fill out this short form to apply. If your interviews are stressful and chaotic right now, I get it — I’ve been there. Let’s make them boring.

metadata.title: I Used to Suck at Coding Interviews. Then I Quadrupled My Salary.
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)System design is my interview kryptonite. Or at least it was. I recently got rejected from a company that I interviewed with months earlier. When I got the feedback I was ecstatic. I passed every round except for the coding challenge where I honestly froze up. It was not my finest moment. So why am I happy.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: It was not my finest moment. So why am I happy. I got the highest marks in the system design round after years of generally being terrible at this style of interview despite managing teams, working with architects and building complex software. I even ran a business years ago working with junior software developers to nail their interviews.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: software developers to nail their interviews. I’m opening a few spots too…Here’s tip number one for anyone prepping for system design interviews:If your strategy is to memorize Alex Xu’s books and regurgitate the answers like a robot then you’re about to fail just like I did. It only took me a few years and many failed system design interviews to learn some expensive lessons that I’ll share with you for free.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: lessons that I’ll share with you for free. In this article, I’ll break down how system design interviews actually work when you’re interviewing outside FAANG, what interviewers are really looking for, and how to stop memorizing and start thinking like a software developer. The System Design Failure ParadeA few months ago, I walked into two different interviews. First one: “Design a rate limiter. ”Second one: “Design a find friends system.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ”Second one: “Design a find friends system. ”If you’ve read System Design Interview Volumes 1 and 2 by Alex Xu, these probably sound familiar. They’re everywhere. Blog posts. YouTube videos. Every Reddit thread that starts with “what should I study for system design interviews. ”And I did study them. I studied the hell out of them. I highlighted the answers. Memorized diagrams. Practiced saying things like “token bucket algorithm” and “eventual consistency” like I actually understood them.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: consistency” like I actually understood them. And then. I bombed. In both interviews, I basically tried to regurgitate the book answers verbatim. No questions, no curiosity, no collaboration. Just a guy trying to recite the right combination of buzzwords so the interviewer would nod and say “you pass. ”They didn’t. Because That’s Not What System Design Interviews Are AboutWhat I learned (painfully, I might add) is this:System design isn’t about getting the right answer. It’s about how you think.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the right answer. It’s about how you think. It’s not a pop quiz. It’s a conversation. When an interviewer asks you to design a rate limiter or a messaging system or an Uber-for-cats app, they’re not trying to see if you can draw boxes and arrows the same way a book did. They want to see how you approach a vague, messy, real-world problem. They want to know:Can you ask clarifying questions. Can you reason through tradeoffs. Can you explain why you’d choose X over Y.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Can you explain why you’d choose X over Y. Can you change your mind when new information comes up. Can you model the problem before throwing tools at it. I didn’t do any of that. Sometimes a “Bad” Idea Is a Great Idea (Context Is Everything)Here’s what books don’t teach you well enough: context is everything. Example: Likes on a social media app. Do they need to be accurate to the second. No. You can batch process likes every few minutes and users won’t know or care.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: every few minutes and users won’t know or care. Do that for banking transactions and you’d have a real problem. Or say you’re designing an internal dashboard. Are you going to spin up Kafka and a micro-services mesh for that. You could. But should you. Probably not. A cron job and a monolith will get you 90% of the way there without turning your app into a distributed mess nobody wants to maintain.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: into a distributed mess nobody wants to maintain. I’ve never seen an example like that in a system design book, where the problems are always at a scale that most software developers will never need to support. What I Do Now (That Actually Works)Once I got over the memorization phase and realized this was about communication, everything changed. Here’s how I approach system design now — and how I’d recommend you do it too:1. Start with a conversationAsk questions. Lots of them. Who are the users.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: questions. Lots of them. Who are the users. How many. What matters more — cost, speed, uptime, consistency. Interviewers want to see your thought process, not just your end result. 2. Model the flow first — not the techWhat happens when a user logs in. Posts a message. Likes a comment. Before you reach for Postgres or Redis or SQS, walk through what actually needs to happen in the system. Write it out. Sketch it. Flow first, tech second. 3.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: it out. Sketch it. Flow first, tech second. 3. Know your toolboxYou don’t need to be a guru in everything, but you do need to know what tools exist and what they’re good for. Relational vs NoSQL. Caching layers. Queues. Streams. CDN. Have a basic understanding of each so you can reach for the right one when it makes sense. If you are totally unfamiliar with these topics, I suggest checking out https://github. com/donnemartin/system-design-primer4.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: com/donnemartin/system-design-primer4. Say it out loud, and invite feedbackThis one was hard for me. I used to be scared of sounding dumb, so I tried to have all the answers upfront. But the best interviews I’ve had were the ones where I said:“Here’s one way I might approach this… but I’d love your input as we go. ”Now you’re collaborating and IF you do begin to go down a poorly planned path, your interviewer can jump in and course-correct. 5. Be ready to change your mindThis isn’t a trick.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 5. Be ready to change your mindThis isn’t a trick. It’s real life. If the interviewer pushes back and says, “Why not just use NoSQL. ” don’t get defensive. Talk about your assumptions, explain your reasoning, and then ask them:“Is there a reason you’d prefer something else here. ”That’s not weakness, it shows that you’re thinking through the problem and genuinely want feedback.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: through the problem and genuinely want feedback. Perhaps they have a good reason or maybe they’re just seeing if you’ll give the right amount of push back for a bad suggestion. The Real TakeawayI lost those interviews because I tried to memorize my way through something that’s supposed to be a conversation. I finally “beat” my last few system design interviews and landed an offer at the top of the range by using the process I outlined here.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of the range by using the process I outlined here. System design interviews aren’t about how much architecture trivia you know. They’re about how you reason, how you communicate, and how you adapt your ideas under pressure. So the next time you’re asked to design something, forget the perfect answer. Talk it through. Explore the tradeoffs. Think like a software architect. It’s about proving you know where to start, where you might be wrong, and how to think your way through it anyway.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and how to think your way through it anyway. I’m going to work with 5 people who want to crush their next interview. This is NOT FAANG prep. Over 8 sessions we will identify your gaps and learn how to nail every aspect of the interview. Apply here.

metadata.title: Why I Bombed My System Design Interviews (And How You Can Avoid It)
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: A Debugging Framework for JS DevelopersIn this mystery — you could also be the suspect. I’m going to share a story of a particularly stressful bug I had to fix years ago while working at a start up and the method I still use to track and fix critical issues in JS code. (yes, even in the age of AI 🙄)The CTO actually mentioned this bug fix when I got promoted. If video is more your thing, you can watch me walk through some tips here.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: you can watch me walk through some tips here. Here we go:It was past midnight on a Thursday when our platform team finished a data migration. It took 3 hours longer than expected and I volunteered to be the front end developer on call to check if everything looked fine on the site after the migration. Easy. Or so I thought. A quick glance over the site showed no obvious errors. Except for one. Our real time line chart was no longer working.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Our real time line chart was no longer working. This is the chart many of our customers proudly displayed in the lobbies of their businesses and executive offices. It looked cool. Not so much when it was flatlining. There were now two options:1. Rollback the entire data migration2. Figure out the cause of this bugIt was late already. I decided to do what any good developer would do at this time and REST. Reproduce the bug locally. Examine the source code. Set breakpoints. Test the fix.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the source code. Set breakpoints. Test the fix. ™️ (patent pending)Reproduce the BugThis real time chart subscribed to websockets through a service that listened for mentions on Twitter for particular phrases. It was past midnight, so it was very possible that we simply weren’t getting any hits. I fired up my local version of the site and searched for “Donald Trump”. It was 2020. This phrase was generating mentions for sure. Still nothing.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: was generating mentions for sure. Still nothing. I opened up the network tab in the chrome developer tools and inspected the incoming messages. We were indeed receiving messages. Ok this was good. But I was secretly hoping this problem was on the back end side. Now it was clear this was a client-side issue. AKA MY issue. Examine the Source CodeI was not familiar with this real time chart and we were going to need to get acquainted in a short time to squish this bug.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: get acquainted in a short time to squish this bug. Our production site minified our JavaScript code which made it difficult (impossible) to read. To check out a suspect file in a Chrome, I opened up the chrome developer tools, clicked on the sources tab and pressed command + p — this opens up a file search where you can choose and inspect a certain file. ahh, beautifulTo prettify the minified code (aka make it human-readable), click on the {} icon in the bottom left corner.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: click on the {} icon in the bottom left corner. Luckily I had this project running locally and was able to dig through the code on my machine. Hmmm. This chart was a simple React component. The data wrangling took place in our redux code which subscribed to a web socket connection. The logic to check if an incoming message should be displayed was a function that looked at two properties in the message object. If those properties matched, then we would display the data. Double hmmm.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: then we would display the data. Double hmmm. Set BreakpointsIt was now past 1AM and I knew the source of this spectacular bug: our redux code and data filtering logic. I’ve seen developers use somewhere north of 20 console logs in their code to debug issues which is an inefficient way to track a bug through JavaScript code. I’ve definitely used this method myself before and it’s confusing and requires lots of refreshing and tinkering with more logs to finally get valuable information.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: more logs to finally get valuable information. Don’t do this. Instead, add a debugger at the source of the error. In this case, I set a breakpoint using the chrome developer tools and stepped through the logic, one line at a time. With the source file open, simply click on the line number where you want to pause execution and wait for this line to be executed to trigger your debugger. Another method is to simply add a debugger statement in the code running locally.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a debugger statement in the code running locally. Walking through the code, the error was now obvious. Our filtering logic was looking for a profile_id property to be available with a value of DUMMY_PROFILE_ID which did not exist on these incoming messages. After doing some quick git history investigation with git log, I saw a developer had recently changed this logic, which used to check for an empty string to now check for this new value. Interesting. It was now 2AM.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for this new value. Interesting. It was now 2AM. I added the fix to our code and our chart worked. The next hour was spent getting this bug fix through our code pipelines and deployed before most of the offices that used our software opened. At 3AM, the issue was finally resolved and I rode the high that you can only get from fixing a production bug at this hour of the morning.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a production bug at this hour of the morning. Test the FixIn my rush to get out the fix, I never really questioned why that developer changed the logic in our redux code. Hey, our real time chart was working, what more proof did I need. While that particular chart was indeed working, others were breaking. Oops.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: was indeed working, others were breaking. Oops. A simple unit test or more thorough testing of all our real time components would have caught this bug but I had tunnel vision and didn’t think of all the other widgets which relied on this real time data and logic. In my defense, it was also 3AM. To avoid these kind of boomerang tickets or bug fixes that lead to other errors, it’s important to add tests. When I hear that there is no time to add tests, I know they’re even more important to add.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: tests, I know they’re even more important to add. Fixing one customer’s issue while spawning bugs for another isn’t the kind of solution you want. Resist the urge to ship code without thorough testing and review. It’s easy to let nerves interfere with judgment. Especially at 3AM. Thanks for reading. By the way, if you’re a JS/TS developer who wants to dominate your next interview (and you know you kinda suck at interviews) apply to work with me here 👉 Application form.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: apply to work with me here 👉 Application form. Skeptical of coding bootcamps. Join Parsity — a 12 month program for serious career changers.

metadata.title: A Debugging Framework for JS Developers
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software DeveloperSimple right. Most people waste their first year learning to code. They bounce between YouTube tutorials, dabble in five languages, and build a graveyard of half-finished projects — then wonder why no one will hire them. This is the 12-month, no-BS roadmap I’d follow if I had to start from scratch in 2025. It’s not pretty. It’s not easy. But it works if you’re willing to show up, put in the hours, and stop chasing quick fixes.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: put in the hours, and stop chasing quick fixes. PS — this is fairly generic. I don’t know you. If you’re looking for a customized plan, with accountability and coaching the go here. First: Let’s Kill the 3-Month MythIf you still believe you can go from zero to job-ready in 3 months in 2025… you’re in for a bad time. That’s a sales pitch, not a plan. A realistic target: 12 months if you’re consistent, intentional, and actually do the work.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: consistent, intentional, and actually do the work. Step 1: Learn One Stack (3–6 Months)Don’t dabble in six languages. Pick one modern, in-demand stack and go deep. If you’re in the U. S. (especially the coasts or near a tech hub), this stack will get you most of the way:HTML + CSS (yes, really — don’t skip them)JavaScript → TypeScript (transition once JS feels natural)React + Next. js (front-end framework + server rendering)Node.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: js (front-end framework + server rendering)Node. js + PostgreSQL (back end + relational database)Git & GitHub (version control + collaboration)Cloud basics (AWS or GCP)Optional: If your local market strongly favors another language (e. g. , Python, C#), learn that too — but no more than one. How to Make This Actionable:Spend 10–20 hours/week minimum on coding (go for consistency over EVERYTHING)Use one primary course or curriculum — don’t bounce around. Stop trying to find the perfect course.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: around. Stop trying to find the perfect course. Pick good enough over perfect. Code daily. Even 30 minutes counts. Push something to GitHub every week. Step 2: Market Development (Start in Month 1)Finding a job is as much about who knows you as what you know. Build your professional visibility while you learn:Get 500+ LinkedIn connections so recruiters can actually find you.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: connections so recruiters can actually find you. Optimize your profile: headline = “Software Developer,” first role = “Software Developer”Create real experience: volunteer, freelance, or join open source projects so you can ethically make your first role say “Software Developer”Post once a week about what you’re learning. Share code snippets, project updates, or mistakes you fixed. Pro Tip: Most people wait until they “feel ready” to start networking. You will NEVER feel ready. Start now.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: networking. You will NEVER feel ready. Start now. Your journey is the content. Step 3: Build ONE Great Project (2–3 Months)Forget “10 projects in 10 days. ” You need one project employers will actually remember.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: need one project employers will actually remember. It should be:Full-stack (separate front end + back end)Publicly deployed (AWS, GCP, or Vercel)Has authentication (login system)Solves a real problem (ideally something you or someone you know would pay for)Portfolio-ready (clean UI, mobile-friendly, good README)Action Plan:Pick a problem you care about. Build a simple but complete solution. (Go for M. U.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a simple but complete solution. (Go for M. U. P — Minimally Usable Product)Document the build process — you’ll reuse it for LinkedIn posts and interviews. Step 4: Go Back-End Heavy (Final 2–3 Months)Even if you aim for front-end roles, being comfortable on the back end makes you far more hireable. Focus on:Node.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: end makes you far more hireable. Focus on:Node. js + PostgreSQL deep diveRole-based authMicroservices vs monolithsCommon DB schema patternsCaching & migrationsCloud deployment (dedicated server setup on AWS/GCP)Step 5: Interview Prep (Last 1–2 Months)You don’t need to grind LeetCode for a year — but you do need to know problem-solving patterns. Use AlgoExpert or a similar platform to learn the main DSA “buckets” (arrays, strings, trees, graphs, recursion).

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: (arrays, strings, trees, graphs, recursion). Do mock interviews — friends, peers, or services like pramp. io. Pro Tip: Practice explaining your thinking out loud. Most beginners bomb interviews because they go silent when stuck. Step 6: BFS Your NetworkTreat networking like a breadth-first search:Ask people you already know for introductions to anyone in tech. Ask those people for their introductions. Repeat. Real Story: My first dev job came from a guy I worked with in a warehouse years earlier.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a guy I worked with in a warehouse years earlier. He became an engineering manager, and his friend vouched for me in the final round. You never know who knows someone. Final ThoughtThis plan will get you 90% of the way to hireable. The last 10%. That’s personalization tailoring this to your situation and getting unstuck fast when you hit a wall.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and getting unstuck fast when you hit a wall. That’s what we do inside Parsity Inner Circle — custom roadmaps, feedback, and accountability so you move faster and don’t waste months spinning your wheels. If you want the custom version of this plan for your life, plus coaching and extreme accountability, check it out here.

metadata.title: The 12-Month, No-Fluff Roadmap to Becoming a Software Developer
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScriptAccording to my reading stats — around 0% of you look like this. The summer of 2013 I decided I was going to be a coder. I already knew HTML and CSS, so I bought this gigantic “JavaScript for Dummies” book. I’m talking phonebook-sized. I read that thing cover to cover all summer as if by the last page I’d suddenly be a developer. I never claimed to be the brightest bulb on the Christmas tree.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to be the brightest bulb on the Christmas tree. I genuinely thought learning all the syntax from a book would mean I could sit down and just… code. I sat down at my computer and had no effing clue what to do by the end of the book. Many of you aren’t as dumb as me but you might be learning JavaScript in a way that’s just as dumb.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: learning JavaScript in a way that’s just as dumb. Fast forward 11–12 years, and I’ve been an engineering manager, senior developer, and even run my own program where I teach people (smarter than me) how to change careers and learn to code. Check it out here. And universally… everybody gets stuck at JavaScript. One guy in particular stands out. When I worked weekends at a coding bootcamp, there was this young man who would come in and study for three to six hours at a time. Every. Single. Weekend.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to six hours at a time. Every. Single. Weekend. Without fail. Every time we met, he was starting over at for loops. It was like his brain hit a reset button every week. I genuinely started to wonder if he had some kind of condition. Finally, I asked him point blank why he thought he could never remember this stuff. His answer. He’d study for those marathon 6-hour sessions on Saturday… and then do absolutely nothing until the next weekend. Mystery solved.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: nothing until the next weekend. Mystery solved. His brain wasn’t broken — his schedule was. The Man Who Knew Nothing Every WeekThat young man’s story is a perfect example of how learning to code like it’s a test for school can NOT work. You can pour six hours into JavaScript in one day, but if you let it sit for a week, your brain treats it like junk mail and tosses it.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: your brain treats it like junk mail and tosses it. Science says: The brain stores skills better through spaced repetition — short, frequent sessions beat marathon sessions because your brain needs downtime to consolidate information into long-term memory (memory consolidation). Even 30–60 minutes a day will beat 3 hours once a week, every time.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a day will beat 3 hours once a week, every time. This is why at Parsity, we spend more time than any other coding bootcamp on the science of learning and teach our mentees how to optimize their learning schedules. What good is curriculum if you can’t retain the info. Fix: Decide on a daily minimum — even 15 minutes counts — and make it non-negotiable.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: 15 minutes counts — and make it non-negotiable. When AI Becomes a TrapI love AI, but if your first instinct is to paste a question into ChatGPT instead of struggling with it, you’re robbing yourself of the exact cognitive process that builds problem-solving skills. Science says: The “desirable difficulty” effect shows that effortful recall and problem-solving strengthen neural pathways far more than passively reading or being given the answer. TLDR; Struggle === growth.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: being given the answer. TLDR; Struggle === growth. Fix: Give yourself a “struggle window” — maybe 20 minutes — before you go to AI. And when you do use AI, explain the solution back in your own words or rewrite it from scratch. The Myth of the One Perfect AnswerA lot of beginners treat JavaScript like a math problem where only one formula works. But programming is more like writing — there are infinite ways to express the same idea.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: there are infinite ways to express the same idea. If you obsess over “the perfect way” or “the exact syntax,” you miss the bigger skill: designing a solution that works. Fix: When you solve a problem, try solving it again — differently. Use a for loop instead of. map. Try for of. Think like a problem-solver, not a syntax collector. Maybe use recursion. If that doesn’t work, maybe use recursion. If that doesn’t work…If you don’t get that lame joke, look up recursion on Google.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: get that lame joke, look up recursion on Google. The Curious Coder vs. The Syntax CollectorWhen I finally started improving, it wasn’t because I mastered filter(). map(). reduce()on toy datasets. It was because I started building janky little projects with HTML, CSS, and some JavaScript slapped on to make things move, pop up, or react.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: slapped on to make things move, pop up, or react. I gave myself small challenges:Make a button do something ridiculousChange the page when you click a cat pictureThe syntax came naturally because I was genuinely curious and motivated to make something work. After writing your 100th for loop — you just don’t need to look it up any more. You can hate me all you want but if you don’t have that curiosity or if building things isn’t fun for you then this industry will not be a good fit.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for you then this industry will not be a good fit. Let me tell you something that isn’t good for my business: there are way too many people trying to get into software who won’t actually enjoy the day-to-day work. If the struggle feels miserable and not worth it, it’s okay to choose a different path. Fix: Manipulate real things with HTML, CSS and JS. Buttons, forms, modals. Build something visual so you can see the cause-and-effect. Aim to get stuck so you can naturally learn along the way.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: stuck so you can naturally learn along the way. Don’t Skip the First Two ChaptersThis guy on TikTok made a reaction video about me. He said my advice was “dangerous. ”My advice:Learn HTML and CSS before JS. I tell you, the internet is full of geniuses. Jumping straight into JavaScript without understanding HTML and CSS is like trying to play jazz before you can keep a beat. You can do it… but you’ll be confused the whole time. HTML and CSS are the canvas and paint — JavaScript is the brush.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the canvas and paint — JavaScript is the brush. Without the first two, your code has nowhere to go. Fix: Spend a week making static sites and styling them. Then, when you add JavaScript, you’ll instantly see how the three work together. 2 Truths and LieJavaScript is hard to learn. It’s even harder when you’re learning it wrong. “Anyone can learn to code” is true in the same way that “anyone can get a six pack. ” Is it possible. Perhaps. Is it likely — absolutely not.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: possible. Perhaps. Is it likely — absolutely not. I believe the most important predictor of your success is curiosity. Small, consistent practice beats intense all-nighters. Delay the AI crutch. Think in solutions, not syntax. Build tangible, visual things. Lay your HTML/CSS foundation first. You can read a hundred books. You can watch a thousand tutorials. You can spend hours scrolling dev Twitter or hanging out in some Discord full of neck-beards.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: hanging out in some Discord full of neck-beards. But until you get your hands dirty, every day, building real things and struggling a little, you will keep restarting at “for loops” forever. At Parsity, we work with small groups with a custom curriculum. We’ve helped bootcamp grads who can NOT land a role to self taught devs who burned out after completing the Odin Project to complete n00bs. We won’t tell you we can help you if we can’t. There’s only one way to find out. Apply here.

metadata.title: This is Why You’re Struggling to Learn JavaScript
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right. Meet your new co-workerThe CEO of AWS recently said that firing junior developers because “AI can replace them” is “the dumbest thing I’ve ever heard. ”Is this even controversial. Depending on who you listen to, you’d think we’re already obsolete. Every week, another company announces layoffs. Even companies reporting record profits — like Cisco — use AI as the excuse to cut jobs. It’s convenient.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: use AI as the excuse to cut jobs. It’s convenient. Not like inflation or tariffs might have something to do with it. But hey, I’m just a lowly software developer and we all know CEOs of massive tech orgs are exceedingly trustworthy. Why people (might) say AI replaces jobsThe money is there. Billions (nearly a trillion) have poured into AI. Investors need a story, and “AI is replacing jobs” is the easiest story to tell. It’s a scapegoat.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is the easiest story to tell. It’s a scapegoat. Execs can trim bloated orgs from pandemic over-hiring and blame AI instead of their own bad planning. Developers became unlikable. For years we posted “day in the life” TikToks — cold brew, kombucha, and $400K salaries to push a button in React. People love to hate us. So when they hear we’re being replaced, they cheer. Can you blame them. It will. There’s almost no doubt that some jobs are more at risk than others.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: doubt that some jobs are more at risk than others. Will it create as many, more or less jobs than it snatches away. Who the hell knows. Reality is messier. Maybe more boring too. Why I don’t believe AI replaces even the worst juniorI use AI every day. Claude, Cursor and ChatGPT. I pay for these tools because I see their value. Here’s what people miss:AI isn’t autonomous.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Here’s what people miss:AI isn’t autonomous. It can’t join a team, understand the context, sit in meetings, parse designs, make changes across a codebase, open a pull request, accept review feedback, and deploy to production. That’s a human loop — maybe forever. The code is excessive. Ask AI for a helper function and you’ll get a novella. Ask it for a data pipeline and you’ll get a brittle mess. The more complex the ask, the more garbage comes back. The “80/20” myth is nonsense.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: garbage comes back. The “80/20” myth is nonsense. People love to say AI does 80% of the work and you just “review” the last 20%. No. Reviewing broken code isn’t 20%. It’s rewriting. I’ve wasted hours chasing AI-generated nonsense before realizing I could’ve written it clean in 15 minutes. Mission-critical code is off-limits. Pipelines that ingest millions of rows, need to scale, and can’t afford inaccuracy — AI isn’t writing those. Its tests are weak. Its assumptions are sloppy.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Its tests are weak. Its assumptions are sloppy. Nobody’s risking revenue streams on it. Here’s the most interesting thing people seem to skip over:AI companies are hiring developers at outrageous salaries. If OpenAI and Anthropic are fighting over talent and still hiring front end, full stack and back end developers — then why on earth would your no-name company think it has the secret sauce. What the research saysCornell and METR recently ran a study on experienced open-source devs.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: ran a study on experienced open-source devs. With AI tools, they actually got 19% slower. Not faster — slower. The devs still thought AI had sped them up. That’s how strong the hype is. So on one side you have the AWS CEO saying firing juniors is idiotic. On the other side you have researchers saying AI actually slows down seniors.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: researchers saying AI actually slows down seniors. And yet… the internet geniusesDespite literal CEOs of cloud giants and researchers studying top open-source devs, there will still be a chorus of self-proclaimed geniuses on LinkedIn, Twitter, Reddit, you name it, telling us we’ve got it all wrong. Apparently they’ve figured out how to use AI the “right” way. Not AWS. Not Cornell researchers. Not anyone else. Just them. Anything is possible… if you just believe. Or lie. Is this your reality too.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: just believe. Or lie. Is this your reality too. Recently I was building a data pipeline to ingest hundreds of thousands of TikTok data points. I asked AI to help with some test cases. At first, the tests looked fine. They were passing. Everything was green. But the actual data flowing through was obviously broken. So I dug deeper. What did I find. The AI had hard-coded return values. In other words: the tests were designed to always pass, no matter what.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: were designed to always pass, no matter what. If I hadn’t checked, we could have shipped something that wasted tons of API credits, dumped millions of rows of junk into our system, and left us with a weekend cleanup job. Obviously, my job is not rubber-stamping AI code. But ask yourself this — would any junior developer do something this nefarious. What would you say if you saw your human colleague make this mistake. That’s not just “oops. ” That’s dangerous.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: That’s not just “oops. ” That’s dangerous. And it shows exactly why AI is not ready to be trusted blindly — especially on critical systems. Don’t take my word for itIf you think AI is already a one-to-one replacement for developers, don’t just argue with me online — test it yourself. Clone a large open-source project. Use AI to try and make a meaningful change. Even better, try to implement a feature or fix a bug and prepare it for a pull request.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: or fix a bug and prepare it for a pull request. (And for the love of God, don’t actually submit the PR. )If AI was really a total replacement, these projects would already be fully automated. They’re not. And if you try it, I doubt you’ll get very far without running into the same problems the rest of us do. That little experiment will give you a very clear picture of AI’s actual capabilities — far more than any headline or hype cycle will. So where does that leave us.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: or hype cycle will. So where does that leave us. Two realities:The hype reality: AI is replacing jobs, productivity is doubled, juniors are toast. The ground reality: AI is helpful and messy. Productivity is marginal at best. Firing juniors is dumb. This is exactly why at Parsity, we’re making a pivot into full stack AI. Don’t you roll your eyes. Ignoring the gold rush would be foolish.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: eyes. Ignoring the gold rush would be foolish. The real opportunities are in building practical apps: retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), smart search, data summarization and integration. Things teams actually need and what companies are happily paying for. We want to teach these skills — because those are the ones that will last after the hype fades and they’re honestly not that difficult to learn. So before you jump into another Twitter fight about AI, try it yourself.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: another Twitter fight about AI, try it yourself. Build something non-trivial. Push it until it breaks. Then you’ll see the difference between hype and reality. We are a small program. We work with everyone one on one. Apply here to learn full stack + AI in a practical way.

metadata.title: A Tale of Two AI Realities: AI Took Away High Paying Tech Jobs… Right?
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling YouSoftware development is undergoing a fundamental change. Just 2 years ago we were shocked that auto-complete tools like GitHub co-pilot were finishing functions for us. Now we have Chet in marketing vibe coding his SAAS app over the weekend. And honestly… it looks pretty damn good. Unfortunately, too many software developers don’t realize the game has changed beyond using code-gen tools like Cursor and Claude.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: using code-gen tools like Cursor and Claude. Extremes are good for social media and stupid for your career. If you follow mainstream media then you probably think it’s over for software developers. Ok. Now what. What do you do. You could hide under a rock or maybe enter a trade that’s less likely to be automated perhaps. What happens when they automate that.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: perhaps. What happens when they automate that. Or you could go just beneath the surface layer, past the hot takes and click bait and take advantage of this monumental shift in how we work. I’m going to share with you how I’m using AI (and NOT using AI) as a software developer, how I’ve seen my job change as well as a specific technology I really think you should be paying attention to that doesn’t get talked about enough. When to AI vs not to AIJust because you can doesn’t mean you should.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: to AIJust because you can doesn’t mean you should. AI can absolutely write your entire web app, data pipelines and backend. Really fast too. It won’t work but it’ll look damn good. The most concerning thing with AI code generation is that less experienced developers often can’t tell the difference between code that works and code that lasts. AI tends to write brittle code that does not consider edge cases, business-specific use cases or maintainability. It simply writes way too much code.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: It simply writes way too much code. The more you rely on it, the higher it will layer on code that acts like a house of cards until eventually…It falls over. Remember this simple rule of code: more code == more surface area for bugsHere are my hard-and-fast rules for when to use AI vs when not to use it. Tedious work that I can easily do but will take a while like updating types in a TypeScript project or breaking up a large component into multiple components. UI updates.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: component into multiple components. UI updates. Drag and drop an image and have AI do its best to get you started. Prototyping. This is where AI really shines. If I’m curious what a large refactor might look like I can just have Claude or Cursor start it off. A proof-of-concept is a perfect use case or any scenario where you don’t care much about code quality. Bug discovery.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: don’t care much about code quality. Bug discovery. From code reviews to thought partner — I will ask Claude or Cursor to poke holes in my logic, ask if I missed any edge cases or suggestions on database schemas. It’s great to either validate my ideas or challenge my assumptions. Code whisperer. I work at a small company and often look over work from our data scientists. I use AI to verify my understanding and explain mathematical concepts that are beyond my simple brain.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: concepts that are beyond my simple brain. Now here’s when I tell my little code monkey to kick rocks:Anything mission critical. If the code breaking means a severe incident might occur then that is generally off limits. TDD. The jury is still out here but I’ve noticed a very sinister phenomenon when AI writes tests for it’s own code — it cheats. Hard-coded return values. Mocking the functions it’s supposed to test so they always pass tests.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: it’s supposed to test so they always pass tests. Pure insanity and now you can’t trust the code OR the tests. When I want a simple solution. I don’t need a rate limiter for this API in an internal web app. I certainly don’t need a README for every component. I don’t need a useless comment above every line of code. TL;DR: AI is like an intern — great to start off with, but increasingly less useful the more complex things get.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: less useful the more complex things get. A new player has entered the chat: RAGI was at a conference in 2023 and the head of Vercel, the company behind NextJS, proclaimed:The AI engineer of the future is a TypeScript engineer. You can imagine how the Twitter mob jumped on this. I’ll admit I was skeptical and wrote it off as rage bait. Then I joined a small startup with some of the smartest people I’ve ever met from the biggest companies in tech.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: I’ve ever met from the biggest companies in tech. The entire app, including our data pipelines to ingest hundreds of thousands of documents and API routes were all in TypeScript. We were using a type of database I’d never heard of — a vector store — to retrieve documents we had scraped from the web and were using to augment AI responses that were being streamed to the front end.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: that were being streamed to the front end. This was my introduction to RAG and I was shocked at how simple it was to get started and how difficult it is to maintain and do correctly. Once you see how useful it is, you can’t un-see it. It felt like I glimpsed into the future. Here we were building an app for Fortune 100 companies using RAG, NextJS, Typescript and Vercel’s AI SDK library.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: NextJS, Typescript and Vercel’s AI SDK library. Turns out many other companies are using RAG — as it’s the most practical use case for AI at the moment but gets a hell of a lot less attention because it requires some actual technical knowledge that doesn’t grab headlines like “[insert jackass CEO] says AI will replace 99.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “[insert jackass CEO] says AI will replace 99. 2% of developers just in time for next quarter’s earnings report”At Parsity we’re going deep into RAG and the core skills you still need as a developer to excel with AND without AI. I’m genuinely excited. Check us out here. You’re the expert… in a room full of expertsWhat happens when billions of dollars in investment meet economic instability at a time when tech bros are elevated to celebrity status.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: when tech bros are elevated to celebrity status. You get hype the likes of which we’ve never seen before. Reality no longer matters. Sam Altman said AI replaces developers in 6 months. Zuckerberg echoes this. Nvidia CEO tells kids not to learn computer science or coding. Newspapers realize the public kinda hates developers and runs stories about our downfall and CS grads flipping burgers. Can you blame them.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and CS grads flipping burgers. Can you blame them. Do you remember those “day in the life” TikToks of 24 year olds doing everything but working at Big Tech and making more than what it costs to buy a 2 story house in the mid west. Perfect storm. We now have managers and CEOs who have never coded anything in their lives telling developers to use AI because it will make them more “efficient” despite any real proof that this is the case.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: despite any real proof that this is the case. A recent study from Cornell discovered the opposite: developers were 19% slower when using AI. Your job is no longer just pumping out code but explaining to the higher-ups the limitations of coding agents and tools like Cursor and Claude. “Why does it take you so long to create a form. I just had ChatGPT make me one in a prompt.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: form. I just had ChatGPT make me one in a prompt. ”Now you have to explain to people who have no business writing code why security, accessibility and complicated API integrations can make “simple” changes take longer than writing a sexy prompt. As annoying as this can be — it’s also good. For too long we’ve told people “anyone” can code. A monkey. Your uncle who can’t open his Hotmail account. A child who can’t multiply yet. AnYonE.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: account. A child who can’t multiply yet. AnYonE. It’s time to learn how to articulate what we do and the value it creates as well as why things are never as simple as they seem. Your job will involve a lot more education and gently letting those just above you understand where the AI hype ends and reality begins. I think this opens up major opportunity for you as a developer trying to climb the corporate ladder.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: a developer trying to climb the corporate ladder. You can be the tech Cyrano de Bergerac for the executive teamAnd FinallyMaybe, just maybe, don’t fall into the doom and gloom narrative OR the overly-optimistic happy path. The problem with the internet isn’t that everyone has an opinion — it’s that the most polarizing ones get the most attention. I’ve had bootcamp drop outs tell me that my job is at stake and no one is hiring.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: me that my job is at stake and no one is hiring. I’ve had career coaches who don’t know what HTML is explain to me that companies simply don’t need junior developers any more because AI can already do whatever it is they think juniors do. These people may all be smarter and even better looking than me. That doesn’t make them right. It also doesn’t make me right. Try the tools. Read the studies. Understand what’s going on just beneath the surface of the tools you use and draw your own conclusions.

metadata.title: Coding in the Age of AI: What No One’s Telling You
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: the tools you use and draw your own conclusions. Good luck out there. If you are more interested in building complex software with AI integrations and learning more about RAG than any coding bootcamp will teach you — then check out Parsity.

content: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”When people first started talking about AI in tech, the promise felt exciting: we have a new tool to push the boundaries of what’s possible. But what it’s turned into is something very different. Today, when someone tells you to “just use AI,” what they really mean is:Do it faster. Not better. Not smarter. Not safer. Just faster. And if the quality is worse. Who cares.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: faster. And if the quality is worse. Who cares. The Hidden Cost of AILet’s make no mistake here: the average quality of what AI produces is worse than what humans produce. One study observed that it slows down senior software engineers by up to 20%. GitHub itself has reported increased bug rates in AI-assisted code. But the uncomfortable truth is that nobody really cares. Companies don’t care about quality if they can shave a few hours off a sprint.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: if they can shave a few hours off a sprint. Investors don’t care if the codebase is brittle as long as the demo works before the next round. And junior developers — many of whom I mentor at Parsity — don’t always realize that relying on AI too heavily is actively hurting their careers. I’ve seen stories of juniors getting fired because they couldn’t actually write code beyond prompting. Remember when we scolded devs for copying and pasting from Stack Overflow.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: devs for copying and pasting from Stack Overflow. Cursor and Claude basically do this at scale. Like a hyped-up intern snacking on Adderral who grinds LeetCode for fun. The Path of Least ResistanceHere’s the sneaky trap: as developers (and humans), our natural instinct is to take the easiest path. Why wrestle with a hard problem when you can just throw it at AI. Why tell your boss something will take three days when you can say, “I’ll use AI, it should only take a couple hours”.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: “I’ll use AI, it should only take a couple hours”. The problem is that easy path leads somewhere ugly: a mountain of brittle, unmaintainable AI-generated code that you’ll eventually have to answer for. Unless, of course, your plan is to jump ship every three months before the fallout hits. A New Flavor of Snake OilThis dynamic has created a new class of snake oil salesmen. I’ve met them. They waltz into companies promising to “build this in record time with AI. ” CEOs eat it up.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: this in record time with AI. ” CEOs eat it up. Who doesn’t want faster AND cheaper. They don’t care about building anything that lasts. They only need to get the company to the next investment round, or to a sellable milestone. After that, the mess is someone else’s problem. Meanwhile, they’ve left behind systems that are fragile, insecure, and dangerous for actual users.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: fragile, insecure, and dangerous for actual users. Look no further than Reddit threads full of developers who lost credentials or exposed sensitive data because someone decided to vibe code with no clue of basic software practices… or common sense. The Skill That Matters NowA lot of people like to make the lazy claim that “coding is going to be obsolete. ”That’s not just wrong, it’s foolish and shows a fundamental lack of understanding of what developers actually do.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: of understanding of what developers actually do. Newsflash — it’s more than writing code and slamming coffees. The role of a developer is changing. But the skill that will matter most isn’t just how well you can code — it’s how well you can push back. Knowing when to say, “No, we can’t use AI for this.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: when to say, “No, we can’t use AI for this. ”Knowing how to explain the limits of our AI toolsKnowing when enough is enoughThat ability to resist pressure, to defend quality, and to protect the long-term health of the product is going to separate the professionals from the prompt jockeys. Push Back, SmartlyI’ve spent the last year working with AI tools myself, watching how they’ve been pushed top-down inside companies, and mentoring developers who are trying to navigate this new landscape.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: who are trying to navigate this new landscape. And my conclusion is simple: your job isn’t to blindly “just use AI. ”Your job is to know when not to. At Parsity we’re teaching full stack and AI in a practical way. RAG, LLM integrations and preparing you for the future of software development beyond writing sexy prompts.

metadata.title: What They Really Mean When They Say “Just Use AI”
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30TLDR; habits. On Easter Sunday of 2012, I stumbled into our family’s tiny condo at 6AM. I was drunk, coming down off an 8-ball of blow and had been in a small car accident with a buddy of mine. This was not an abnormal night for me. An hour later, I would have an intervention. There were tears, cussing and lots of doubt. I had been smoking since 14, drinking since 17 and experimenting with drugs since 13.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: since 17 and experimenting with drugs since 13. The next year I was working as a software engineer and running 3 miles a day. I’m still sober in case you’re wondering. I do smoke a 1 or 2 cigars a year (my daughter hates it). In the last decade, I’ve gone from a pudgy, booze-guzzling drug abuser to making my personal trainer’s fitness page, managing a team of software engineers, owning a business and becoming a cringy influencer on LinkedIn (don’t roll your eyes too hard).

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: on LinkedIn (don’t roll your eyes too hard). Things aren’t all roses and candy canes. I still have strong urges to back slide and I have serious self doubt. I honestly don’t know if I should be writing these kinds of articles. Will people think I’m bragging. What if a future customer or employer reads this. Who am I to tell you anything.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: reads this. Who am I to tell you anything. First off, I’m not here to sell you anything (unless you want to change careers into software — then I absolutely have a program called Parsity which you should check out). Ok — sales hat is off. I sincerely want to share what I’ve learned in the hopes it can help you. Whether you want to lose weight, change careers or quit hard drugs, you already know what you need to do for the most part. Knowledge is not the blocker. Action is what you need.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: is not the blocker. Action is what you need. Unfortunately, you probably believe building habits is a game of will power. Which is why you lose the game. The path to success and failure are the same. Your habits will make or break you. You are not who you think you are. You are what you do. Habits create grooves in our brain. They make our life easier by reducing cognitive overload. They sneak into our lives in response to the emotional roller coaster that is life. Making decisions is taxing.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: coaster that is life. Making decisions is taxing. Habits are the shortcut for decision-making. The problem is that most of us have not been intentional when we create habits. They just kind of snuck up on us. Now we’re “stuck” with them. You pass by a box of donuts at work and eat more than you expected. You sit in bed and scroll endlessly. You have a glass or 3 of wine after dinner. It doesn’t have to be this way. I stumbled upon the recipe for creating habits when I quit drugs and alcohol.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: for creating habits when I quit drugs and alcohol. When people ask how I did it, I could not articulate what my process was. Turns out, I was following a proven method without even knowing it. You cannot destroy a habitBut you can replace it. Remember, your habit is a response to something. Identify what that something is. For me, I liked to get wasted because I was insecure. It was also my only hobby.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: because I was insecure. It was also my only hobby. The first weekend I spent without drinking made me painfully aware of just how long a sober day is. It’s long af. When I got the urge to drink I would take a walk to the liquor store near our house and buy snacks and lotto tickets. I stuffed my face with candy and scratched hundreds of dollars of tickets for a few months to fight off the urges. It worked. I also became pretty fluffy and broke. Then something interesting happened.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: and broke. Then something interesting happened. What’s your trigger. I was sober but fat. I didn’t like my job. I still didn’t feel any more confident. Then I found coding. My true replacement addiction. I am now owner of Parsity. io — an online coding school where we turn busy career changers into professional coders. Learning how to code satisfied 2 of 3 requirements for replacing my old habit of getting obliterated:It gave me confidence. I felt smarter and proud to learn something difficult.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: smarter and proud to learn something difficult. I had something to do on my weekends and week nights. There was still something missing. At the heart of my addiction was deep insecurity. I still struggle with this. Coding made me feel better but I still didn’t like what I saw in the mirror. I had no clue what to do in a gym so I decided to start running at the field across the street from our house. I was over 200 pounds and my lungs were toast from 15 years of smoking menthols.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: were toast from 15 years of smoking menthols. I could barely run half a mile. Running released some of that sweet dopamine I craved and it only took 20 minutes to get it cranking. The dopamine kept me coming back. Once my body started changing I was too afraid to stop. Compound interestI had identified my triggers — free time in the evenings and insecurity. My new habits were responses to the same cues. I got a rush from the running. I killed time with learning to code. Then things snowballed.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: with learning to code. Then things snowballed. At the risk of sounding like a cringy influencer, I did all the things cringy influencers do:MeditatingJournalingReading self-help booksSaving and investingMeme coin scam coming soon. One habit led to another and yet another. Within a year my life changed dramatically. In the next 5 years, I was unrecognizable. I used the same pattern to quit drinking that I used to start journaling in the evenings when I would usually scroll on my phone.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: evenings when I would usually scroll on my phone. I identified my trigger — going to bed. To interrupt the pattern with a replacement, I simply bought a 99 cent journal and put it on my night stand. Sounds too simple right. Try it. The dark side of habitsI never went to AA, therapy or had any professional treatment for my addictions. My obsessive mindset might not be normal or even healthy. I work nearly 7 days a week to keep myself busy. I don’t need to work this much but I do.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: busy. I don’t need to work this much but I do. The day after I had a heart-related issue, I was back to doing 300 push ups at the park. My habit took over my decision making process. It was foolish in hindsight. Creating habits is a super-power. With great power comes great responsibility. What’s behind the habit you want to create. How long should it last and when can it be “retired”.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: long should it last and when can it be “retired”. At this point, I am more intentional with my habits and I strongly suggest you think about the purpose of your habits and the kind of person you want to be. Here’s a question I have for you — “What do you truly want. ”Hard one huh. I’m still trying to figure that one out myself. It’s a hell of a lot easier when you have habits that aren’t walking you down a path you never intended. If this article helped in any way then I’m slightly happier.

metadata.title: How I Gained 30k Followers, Lost 50 lbs and Switched Careers after 30
metadata.author: Brian Jenney

content: helped in any way then I’m slightly happier. Good luck you bandicoot.
